name: Court of Fontaine Region
desc:
"This city alone stands above all waters."

Towering up at the highest point of the city, the Palais Mermonia represents the highest authority in Fontaine. Under its gaze, the people lead orderly lives that are as regular and predictable as the aquabus.

Law serves to maintain a stable order, which is in turn the cornerstone that equity and justice are built upon.

customize.text: Character Level-Up Materials

customize.name: Artificed Spare Clockwork Component — Coppelius
customize.desc:
An artificed spare clockwork component belonging to Coppelius. It powers this artificed dancer.

The artificed dancer whirls to a platinum tune, performing an unending waltz of icewind. Coppelius's dance will not stop. He will continue whirling till the bell tolls.

customize.name: Artificed Spare Clockwork Component — Coppelia
customize.desc:
An artificed spare clockwork component belonging to Coppelia. It powers this artificed dancer.
According to its creator's design, the story of the artificed dancer with delicate joints ends at a merry moment. Coppelia will send whoever attempts to disturb that moment to a chapter of misfortune with her superb combat skills.

customize.text: Boss Materials

customize.name: Lightless Mass
customize.desc:
A fragment produced from the intense battle against the All-Devouring Narwhal.

The universe is a dark and cold place.

But look carefully. Inside are always faint glimmers of light, like pearls gleaming from within the sand, splinters of diamond sprinkled over asphalt, lights lancing through the fog on a misty night, and sparks that ignite the brightest blazes.

customize.name: Lightless Silk String
customize.desc:
A slender strand that somehow ended up entangled on your weapon while fighting the All-Devouring Narwhal.

In ancient Fontaine, some thought that Fortuna, which ruled the world, was woven from countless fibers, like the strings of a harp. Strings that resonate with the majestic music would bring happiness to all, while discord would destroy the fabric of the universe.

customize.name: Lightless Eye of the Maelstrom
customize.desc:
A strange "substance" obtained from fighting against the All-Devouring Narwhal. Its actual weight far exceeds what would be expected given its size.

Everything gathers around heavy objects, just as gold attracts more than iron, or the ground more than in the breeze blowing above. Just as light cannot escape from the vortex of darkness, cause and effect is attached to fate, perhaps irreversibly so.

customize.text: Gadgets

customize.name: "Opera House Switcheroo" Case Record
customize.desc: A detailed case record of the murder and the disappearance that occurred during Lyney and Lynette's switcheroo magic show in the Opera Epiclese. If any difficulties are encountered during the investigation, please examine the clues and evidence collected so far to gather and organize your thoughts.

customize.name: "Water and Missing Person" Case Record
customize.desc: A detailed case record of the murder related to Navia's father, Callas, and the serial disappearances of young women case that is thought to be closely linked to the murder. If any difficulties are encountered during the investigation, please examine the clues and evidence collected so far to gather and organize your thoughts.

customize.name: Wavepiercer
customize.desc:
If you can stay within the Ideal Tension Zone while fishing, this rod will shorten the time in which fish will struggle by a stable amount and increase your chances of success. This effect only works in Fontaine.

A slender fishing rod with a beautiful metallic glamor. Made of innovative metal materials designed by the Fontaine Research Institute, it combines light weight and resistance. Thanks to the solid metal loops reinforcing the connections between each section, the rod is capable of bearing fish of astonishing weight. Moreover, the reel seat is modeled after the handguards on weapon handles, protecting the angler from being damaged by fierce and "tough" fish.

According to experienced fishers, this rod is the perfect weapon against "Iron Fish," the specialty of Fontaine, and is comparable to a trusty lance.

customize.name: Hydro Treasure Compass
customize.desc:
A compass that can be used in Fontaine to search for nearby chests.

These chests scattered across Fontaine are not the lawful property of any individual or organization. In most circumstances, it is legal to claim the contents found within.

customize.name: Hydroculus Resonance Stone
customize.desc:
A talisman that can be used in Fontaine to search for nearby Hydroculi.

A curious talisman that possesses similar properties to the Hydro Statues of The Seven. It seems to be able to detect the Elemental Flow of Hydroculi.

Oculi are by nature scattered pieces of power belonging to the Statues of The Seven. Returning them to the Statues is therefore the reasonable, right, and lawful thing to do.

customize.name: Crystalfly Trap
customize.desc:
A Crystalfly Trap, developed by a senior researcher named Fawitzki from Fontaine Research Institute of Kinetic Energy Engineering.

After being properly deployed and inserting the required materials, this device will start working and lure Crystalflies inside.

Fawitzki once led research on "Low-Temperature Lighting Devices," which required a large amount of Crystal Cores as research materials, which led to the development of the Crystalfly Trap.

However, the project was suspended for various reasons.

"We are here to commemorate the diligent Mr. Fawitzki. We sincerely hope that there are those who will carry on his research. The Institute will provide maximum support in any areas deemed appropriate."

customize.name: Wind-Powered Wind Generator
customize.desc:
A wind generating device developed by Refait, senior researcher from Fontaine Research Institute of Kinetic Energy Engineering.

After being activated, this device can provide a strong lifting force for the Wind Glider user.

However, due to design limitations, the device requires utilizing significant wind power to activate. The wind energy required is approximately equal to that produced by the working Wind Glider.

"Umm... So you mean I can only activate this device when I'm already using the Wind Glider."

"But the only reason I even want to activate it is to give my Wind Glider a push!"

customize.text: Living Beings
Enemies and Monsters

customize.name: Icewind Suite
customize.desc:
Artificed Dancers developed by the Fontaine Research Institute.

Bossuet originally intended for Artificed Dancers to be works of art that transcended the era of mechanical reproduction. But after Bossuet was forced to resign, the project was taken over by Maillardet, who had his own unique understanding of what he wanted to achieve. As a result, while their features were perfected during the course of its development, the Artificed Dancers gradually strayed from Bossuet's original vision.

customize.name: All-Devouring Narwhal
customize.desc:
A mysterious and gargantuan creature from another world.

Poets often liken the starry sky to the ocean. They've seen or dreamt of countless bioluminescent plankton floating on a moonless sea, resembling a galaxy, or the moonlight ripped apart by waves on the sea's surface, like shimmering stars. In the most fantastical stories or outrageous lies, the stars found in the depths of the cosmos might be teeming with life, much like Teyvat, and the universe itself is akin to an ocean. Realistically speaking, however, if a profound universe full of life exists, why hasn't any of that life made contact with Teyvat?

Maybe the universe has been constantly trying to infiltrate Teyvat, or maybe a higher power created borders to protect this world.

customize.name: Euphrasie
customize.desc: Euphrasie is the Chief Editor of The Steambird. She shoulders a great many responsibilities in addition to her work at the agency — she posts commissions for local residents' everyday troubles, assists the Palais Mermonia in putting up posters for criminals and dangerous monsters wanted by the Maison Gardiennage, and taps into the newspaper's powerful sources to find and contact people best suited for the missions... If you can solve problems for local citizens, maintain the order of the wilds of Fontaine, and build up your reputation steadily, you may earn rewards from different clients via Euphrasie...

customize.text: Adventure Guides
Tutorials
Map
Location Map
Smuggling Case

One day, the magician's assistant, Lynette, found a cat in the Court of Fontaine and named it Bonnie. She tried to find Bonnie's owners by placing an ad in The Steambird, and a man and a woman answered her ad. After examining the cat, the man decided that he had made a mistake, and the woman said that the cat belonged to her friend. Lynette suspected that the woman might be a Garde, so she revealed her name, Elodie. Elodie was investigating a case of smuggling across the border, and the real owner of the cat was one of her main suspects. When he realized that the Gardes were looking for him, he ran away and was separated from Bonnie. Elodie hoped that the owner might return for the cat, so she answered the ad in the newspaper.
Elodie revealed that Bonnie's owner was Pierre Lefevere, a researcher at the Fontaine Research Institute. The Lefevere family was once a famous aristocratic family involved in many crimes. One of the family members "bought" Lynette many years ago, before she joined Fatui and the House of the Hearth. In recent years, almost all the family members, including the head, were killed by an unknown assassin. Most of the remaining members died of hunger and disease, and the survivors changed their names. Pierre hid in the institute under a different name, but when the Gardes searched his belongings, they found a pendant of an illegitimate member of the Lefevere family.
The contraband that Pierre was transporting was a new type of drug called the Imitation Sinthe. When the Gardes confiscated all Sinthe and arrested the head of the Confrerie of Cabriere, Marcel, who was behind the production of Sinthe, people began to look for a new way to get drugs. Due to the measures taken after the Sinthe incident, criminals became smarter and managed to transfer their sales abroad. When the Marechausse Phantom began an investigation to track down all the people in Fontaine who were capable of producing such a drug, they came across Pierre. Elodie knew that if she took Bonnie to the Gardes, Pierre would definitely not come for it, so she asked Lynette and the Traveler to keep an eye on the cat.
Lynette felt that something was wrong with Pierre's story, so she went to the Fontaine Research Institute to find the truth. There, she met her brother Lyney and the captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, Chevreuse. As Lynette suspected, her brother, who had been acting suspiciously in recent days, was investigating Pierre Lefevere. Chevreuse and Lyney revealed that Pierre had become addicted to Sinthe, so he tried to use the Institute's resources to create a substance with a similar effect. Although Pierre claimed he had done this only for research purposes, the Institute denied him access to the relevant materials. He was placed on leave until the investigation was completed, but due to staff shortages, the investigation was postponed.
Since the Imitation Sinthe left clear traces at the production sites, Lynette, Chevreuse, Lyney, and the Traveler investigated a suspicious place on the coast near the Thalatta Submarine Canyon. From the evidence they collected, they concluded that Pierre was using floating barrels to transfer drugs and had an accomplice. If Pierre was only responsible for producing the Imitation Sinthe, the second person would have to be responsible for transporting the goods across the border. Lynette and the Traveler went to the Lumidouce Harbor to examine the registration logs and look for clues.
Once at the harbor, Lynette and the Traveler discovered that the gendarme Elodie was in charge of protecting Lumidouce Harbor. In the registration logs, they found records of a "Humane Society" that rehomed animals abroad. The head of the organization was Bernard, the man who responded to the ad about Bonnie. Lynette and the Traveler figured out that the Humane Society was using cats to transport the Imitation Sinthe so that no one could detect it. Pierre fed the drugs to the cats in special corrosion-resistant bags and transported them in floating barrels with holes for air. When Bernard examined Bonnie, he felt her stomach to make sure she did not have the Imitation Sinthe.
When Lynette, the Traveler, and Elodie arrived at the Humane Society in the Court of Fontaine, they captured Bernard. He admitted that the organization was in a sorry state, but one day he received an unexpected letter. He was offered a large sum of money to transport animals abroad, and he accepted. Although Bernard constantly communicated with Pierre by letter, he never met him in person. When the Marechaussee Phantom began investigating, Bernard received a final letter stating that Pierre had gone on the run.

After Bernard was caught, Lynette felt that the case had been solved too quickly. Since Pierre was so careful and secretive, it was suspicious that he carried a pendant with him that linked him to the Lefevere family. The Institute had cut off Pierre's access to the materials, but he somehow continued to make the Imitation Sinthe. The letter that Bernard had received also seemed strange: if Pierre had known that Bonnie did not have the drug, he could have warned Bernard about it. And if the cat had them, she would have been the main evidence that had to be disposed of. Having collected all the evidence, Lynette and the Traveler came to the conclusion that there was a third person in the case, unknown to both Pierre and Bernard. And this third person had long ago decided to sacrifice them for the sake of their own salvation in the case.

Lynette and the Traveler realized that all this time, only one person had been leading them astray by telling them that Pierre belonged to the Lefevere family: Elodie. She was the one who had set the Marechaussee Phantom on Pierre and then lured him into a trap so that he would disappear. She was the one who had led the investigation to the "Humane Society" by noticing their name in the registration logs. Elodie had organized the records of the society's activities when filling out the logs in such a way that anyone reading them would immediately notice, and the logs themselves did not contain information about the port administration's activities during the shifts that Elodie worked. In addition, she often changed shifts, and they coincided exactly with the activities of the "Humane Society."
Elodie's real name was Elodie Lefevere, and she was the illegitimate daughter of the family. She became a Garde before the fall of the Lefeveres, and actively participated in the interrogations and arrests of family members in order to avoid suspicion. Thanks to the help of Chevreuse and Lyney, who arrived in time, Elodie was caught and taken into custody.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Marechaussee Phantom
customize.desc: The personal unit of the Chief Justice Neuvillette, which is responsible for crime investigation. It is based in the Palais Mermonia and is one of the Maison Gardiennage's departments.

customize.name: Lynette
customize.desc: A magic assistant of few words, her emotions are as inscrutable as any cat's.

customize.name: Lyney
customize.desc: A famed Fontainian magician who possesses great stage presence as well as gift of the gab. Audiences are enthralled by his exquisite skills, and they hang on to his every clever word.

customize.name: Chevreuse
customize.desc: The captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, who wears justice as an ever-present seal upon her heart. Her musket shall only ever point at the guilty.

customize.text: "The Little Oceanid"

Once the director of a small theater troupe, Aurelie Fumeau, gathered around herself many people who were left without a livelihood or who had lost the meaning of life, and convinced them to join her troupe. She wrote scripts herself, performed on stage, and mentored each of them. Dulphy was born with an incurable illness, and once her family found out it couldn't be treated, they abandoned her. For several years, she agreed to any job, tried to manage her illness with various medicines, and during a severe flare-up, she lay in an alleyway for days at a time. When Aurelie found Dulphy, she said that she had a beautiful voice and offered to teach her to sing. The director taught her to sing and perform, helped her find money for medicine, and took care of her. Another actor, Lauwick, was the son of a murderer and grew up in an orphanage. Other children bullied and beat him, and one day he ran away. When he had already lost all faith in humanity, he met Aurelie. The actor Pauleau was in love with Aurelie. One day, he confessed his feelings to her, but she said that the whole troupe was like siblings to her. Pauleau replied that he would always help the troupe and her and hoped that in the future she would be able to rethink what she wanted in her life.

Aurelie's last work was the musical "The Little Oceanid", which tells the story of a young Oceanid who, despite her family's protests, turned into a human. She dreamed of living like everyone else and even found friendship and love. Everything seemed perfect, but one day her true nature was revealed, and her world began to crumble. <color=#ffffffd9>"If you become human, you can reveal your secret to no one. You will face suffering and loneliness... Is this truly what you want?"</color> This was the most important line in the entire script and a symbolic statement about the life and legacy of the troupe's leader. She kept silent about all the trials and tribulations that befell her as the troupe's leader and devoted all her energy to them. Aurelie never managed to finish the play, as she became a victim of serial disappearances. Among the belongings of the young girls dissolved by the killer, Vacher, was Aurelie's diary. When the girl was dissolved before her eyes, the diary broke off. It turned out that she was trying to protect her troupe because one of the members got involved in distributing Sinthe. Before she disappeared, she told everyone to leave the Court of Fontaine and wait for her outside the city, but she never came. Even as she sat in silence, waiting for her death, she did not regret her decision, because she was an older sister to the troupe.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Someone else was taken. That makes six.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Or perhaps the seventh? Someone tried to escape yesterday but was caught. She hasn't been seen since.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Was that yesterday? Maybe not. I've long since lost track of time.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Sorry. I don't know if writing this is of any use, or how much longer I can do it for.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>I can already see my fate approaching. But what terrifies me even more is...</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>The thought of seeing others from the troupe here.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Have I truly protected them?</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Sorry. I'm so sorry. I can write no more...</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>I think I have a fever and my old stomach troubles have returned. But nobody has given me any medicine.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>I suppose I am more fortunate than Crecy... the pain keeps her awake all night.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>I suppose they think that anything goes so long as the experimental subjects can be used up before they die...</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>It is so damp here. I have given her my blanket.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>So cold, so cold. So cold.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>As long as one persists, all things will pass.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>There will be a reward for hard work.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>I like to tell them such things.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>But it is I who am losing my grip."</color>

Since the troupe lost its leader, everything went downhill. Conflicts began to arise between them, the chronic illness of the lead actress worsened, the two main actors did not give confirmation, and the troupe could not agree on the ending of the play. Some believed that it was worth making a happy ending so as not to convey their pain to the audience, while others believed that it was worth writing a real tragedy, like in life. Pauleau, playing the main character's beloved, locked himself in the house to concentrate on writing the ending. When the deadline came, there was still no news from him. Vilmant, playing the main villain, took Aurelie's death very hard and did not appear in the city. It was he who caused the death of the leader. Since the troupe stayed afloat thanks to donations from the audience, their financial situation was difficult. One day after a performance, a merchant approached Vilmant and offered generous sponsorship, and in exchange, the troupe would provide the audience with drinks during the performances. Vilmant thought it was a good deal and agreed without even consulting Aurelie. When the merchant came to pick up the goods, it turned out to be Sinthe. He immediately explained everything to the leader, and she told the merchant that the troupe could not agree to this collaboration. In a rage, the merchant threatened to sue for damages, but Aurelie promised to solve the problem herself. Suddenly, she ordered everyone to leave the city and never returned.

When Dulphy's illness worsened, Lauwick approached the Adventurers' Guild to find a replacement, but since the show was in a few days and the troupe had no extra funds, no one would agree. The Traveler and Paimon answered the call and decided to ask Furina, who had left her post as the Hydro Archon, to perform in the musical. She was categorically not ready to return to the stage but agreed to consult with the troupe to learn more about their leader. The story of "The Little Oceanid" resonated deeply with Furina, as she had hidden her true nature for centuries and could not confess to anyone.

Pauleau's proposed scenario told how an Oceanid found love and friendship in a bustling city, but people began to notice that all the fresh water in the area was gradually disappearing, the soil was becoming dry, and the plants and flowers were withering. Little Oceanid Clio and her lover decided to do something and get to the bottom of it together. Eventually, they discovered that all the waste and pollution created by people over the years had caused the fresh water to leave the earth as if driven by its own consciousness. Clio, as a water spirit, immediately understood what the water felt and told her lover about it and her true nature. Her lover accepted her as she was, and together, they tried to find a way to bring back the water, but someone overheard her secret and blamed her for the disappearance of the water. In the end, she made the courageous decision to sacrifice herself to save her lover and all of humanity.

Dulphy wanted to make the most truthful ending possible, with the little Oceanid reflecting Aurelie. She proposed that the little Oceanid be hunted to death by the people who hated her, her lover ensured that her secret would never be revealed, and humanity would continue on its path to extinction. This ending would show the random and meaningless end that their leader met, sacrificed for the sake of an experiment by a man who had no relation to her. Pauleau, who was in love with Aurelie, did not agree with this ending, as he wanted a better ending for her. Together, they decided to go to Vilmant to reach a compromise on the script.

When the troupe learned the truth about Aurelie's death, some were furious, but Furina helped them put their differences aside until the end of the performance. The troupe's leader wanted to build a warm home for all her brothers and sisters and shield them from the storms that rage in the world outside. Although the troupe tried to make her the heroine of the story, she was already a heroine to them. And if the troupe wanted to do justice to Aurelie, they had to reconcile their differences and force themselves to finish the play. After reading Aurelie's diary, found in the evidence at the Palais Mermonia, the troupe unanimously decided on the ending of the musical.

During the final performance at the Opera Epiclese, which Furina had helped to book, Dulphy's illness worsened again, and she asked Furina to sing the final song. Although Furina had broken her promise to herself never to go on stage again, she was glad to be back. In the last scene, Clio sacrificed herself to bring back fresh water and save the people. According to the script, she was not to take up the Vision that would appear before her as she disappeared, but instead allow it to fall into the ocean depths alone. But during the actual performance, a real Vision appeared, and it belonged to Furina. As Furina grasped it, its reflected radiance seemed to contain her heart, filled once again by this performance.

<color=#ffffffd9>"If I could only return to the water's embrace</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Wouldn't the world be a lovelier place?</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Dear Mother, would you be able to forgive</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>As the dancing water flows, so too we would live</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>The city would nourish</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>And you too, my dear, would flourish</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>But love alone could be to no avail</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Only farewell, I fear, would prevail</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Thus are our lives filled with joy and sorrow</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>I'll be here always, forever and tomorrow</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>To behold the world's undying beauty</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>And that shall live on in perpetuity…"</color>

Despite the great success of "The Little Oceanid," the actors decided to disband the troupe. Some of them were ready to continue acting, while others wanted to take care of their health. Furina, inspired by Aurelie's life, decided that she was not as against returning to the stage as she had previously thought. From that moment on, she wanted to spend her time learning real stories about real people and how they touch the lives of others around them. She wanted to watch them blossom and wither, see them refined on the page, retold on the stage, and remembered long into the future.

customize.text: The Phantom Weasel

More than ten years ago, a phantom thief, known as "The Weasel," became active in the Court of Fontaine. Nobody knew his true identity, and the authorities never managed to catch him. He had a bad reputation: he targeted whatever people held dear, and no one was safe from his predation. He would just as soon steal a necklace from a rich merchant's safe as he would a toy doll given to a commoner child for their birthday. If not for an accident, The Weasel could have continued to roam free, but ten years ago, a magician named Cesar fell to his death in a botched high-altitude escape performance. When the police went through his personal effects, they found a hoard of stolen loot and gadgets used for criminal activities, and that was how The Phantom Weasel's identity was revealed to all. Many did not believe that Cesar could be a criminal, because he was constantly giving gifts to children. Sometimes he would ask them to write down what they wanted on paper, and during the next performance, he would pull the gifts out of thin air. But after his death, a rumor spread that Cesar had asked children to write their wishes on paper so that he could steal their most precious possessions. After Cesar's death, there were fewer thefts in the city, and people began to forget about him, until one day, ten years later, The Weasel wrote a warning letter and hung it right on the gates of the opera house: <color=#ffffffd9>"Three days from now, when evening falls, I shall take from you that which you hold most dear at the opera house, just as you did to me ten years ago."</color>
Three days later, the magician Lyney was scheduled to perform at the Opera Epiclese in the evening, so he wanted to expose The Weasel so that his concert would not be canceled. He asked the Traveler and Paimon to join the investigation and temporarily act as his assistants. The first step was to find out who Cesar really was, because if he truly was The Phantom Weasel, the real Weasel would be dead, and the warning letter was just a copycat criminal. And if he was not The Weasel, the real Weasel would be alive and have gone into hiding ten years ago. They decided to start with Cesar's fiancée, Jemma, who visits his grave every week. She often spoke into the void and told him the latest news. People thought that Cesar did not deserve the love of such a woman, because he was a criminal. When Jemma appeared at the cemetery, she was wounded and looked scared, so she refused to answer Lyney's questions. Even though they left her alone, it felt like she was hiding something.
The next day, they decided to meet Cesar's student Lorenzo, who had inherited his secrets of magic and craft. Before long, Lorenzo was the next big magician in town, his fame surpassing even that of his master, and it made him very wealthy. He's since left the magic scene and became a wealthy businessman with his fingers in a lot of different pies. He claimed that the real Weasel had died, and it was the imitator who left the letter. <color=#ffffffd9>"Look, you of all people should know that a magician never reveals their secrets — and in any case, dead men don't talk. So if you really care about your magician's pride, then you'll forget about Cesar and move on."</color> The conversation with Lorenzo also did not give answers, but left the feeling that he was hiding something. Leaving Lorenzo, Lyney noticed surveillance. These people threatened Jemma and wanted to deal with Lyney and the Traveler, but were defeated. Lyney assured Jemma that she was not in danger, and she told him about Cesar's workshop in the Fleuve Cendre.

The path to the workshop was protected by tricks and riddles, and the workshop itself was hidden behind a secret door in the closet. Inside was Cesar's diary, where he talked about meeting two children who wanted to learn how to do tricks. They were so persistent in their requests that Cesar could not refuse them. The children turned out to be incredibly talented and had unusual thoughts, so the magician was sure that over time, they would surpass him. Cesar even wanted to take them on tour, but they refused, and one day he overheard them talking about "Father" and the "mission." As they parted, he shared with them his view of the world: <color=#ffffffd9>"It's full of lies and falsehoods, and that is why we must find our own truth."</color>

In addition, there was a box for a "high-altitude escape" trick in the workshop. During this trick, the magician slots themselves into a magic box in full view of the audience. The box is then suspended high in the air, and a short while later, the base automatically opens. At this point, a dummy will fall out of the box, but it looks real enough to grab the audience's attention, and they start wailing and screaming. Meanwhile, the real magician, who has by now blended into the crowd, waits for a good moment to make their appearance and puts on a hysterical performance: <color=#ffffffd9>"Oh no! Is that me!? Did I just fall to my death!?"</color> The audience's gaze then turns to the magician, and by the time they realize what's happened, the dummy has vanished — as if everything that just happened was some sort of shared illusion. Cesar himself invented this trick but was never able to perform it. When the box opened, it was not the dummy that fell out, but the magician himself. The box was hanging under the highest point of the opera house, and Cesar fell down from there. Since he was an ordinary man without a Vision, he could not hope to survive that fall.

Cesar constructed the box for the performance himself. Inside, there was a device that only the magician himself would know about. Once the magician is inside and the box is lifted up into the air, the audience's view of the box is fixed at a certain angle. From where they're standing, they have a clear view of the front, sides, and bottom, but the back and the top are no longer visible. At this point, the magician presses a button inside the box, opening a secret door out of view. For the trick to succeed, the magician must constantly keep the audience in suspense. Many days and nights of careful research and painstaking practice would have gone into this, all culminating in a performance just a few minutes long, but one that still manages to transform the shock and grief of a tragic accident into the joy and laughter of a mesmerizing magic trick.

The magic box Cesar was using at the time of his death had the secret button positioned on the right-hand side, and he always used his right hand as his dominant hand in public. However, most of the props were equipped with mechanisms on the left-hand side, and the box in the workshop also had a button on the left. Cesar pretended to be right-handed, since a magician can't afford to have their most basic habits stand out too much. People naturally focus their attention on the most important details of the task or situation at hand, but a magician needs to be able to redirect an audience's attention at will, so as to avoid arousing their suspicion. The essence of magic is getting people to believe a lie. If even the truth raises eyebrows, the falsehoods become all the more difficult to mask. Cesar had to pretend to be right-handed so that the audience did not notice anything. But in his most stressful and nerve-wracking moments, and when no one was watching, a reflex would kick in, and he'd use his left hand, so he placed the button in the box on the left.

During the trick, Cesar had to get a dummy in a matter of seconds, throw it down to distract the audience, and then open a secret door and get out. Someone took advantage of the fact that he was left-handed and switched the box. When the magician reached for the button with his left hand, it was not there. He spent a few extra seconds searching, and then the bottom of the box automatically opened.
Only a person close to Cesar had access to the props and knew which hand was Cesar's dominant, as close as his student Lorenzo was. It was his people who threatened Jemma and Lyney. He admitted that he hated Cesar because he forbade him from using tricks to get rich, while he poured everything into his street performances. Every other apprentice was living it up at their master's expense, but Lorenzo lived in poverty. He was afraid to leave since one word from Cesar could ruin his life, so he decided to kill his mentor. Lorenzo also admitted that he was The Weasel, but Lyney did not believe him.

The next day, during Lyney's performance, Lynette accused Jemma of being The Weasel all along. Her parents died young, and the orphan had to fend for herself. She'd scrounge waste paper from garbage bins to draw on, using twigs and dirt for lack of ink and pen. She'd sew ugly ragdolls from whatever scrap material she could get her hands on. At that tender age, she should have been happy, instead, she stood in the shadows and watched with envy as all good things in the world passed her by. Her pain became a breeding ground for dark thoughts, and she began to hate people's happiness, be it rich or poor.

At the time when The Weasel was terrorizing the entire Court of Fontaine, the police were deploying more and more forces to stop her. So, The Weasel came up with a cunning plan: to hang her crimes on someone else, and she settled on a renowned magician, Cesar. She deceived him into trusting her and realized that the magician had a pupil who harbored a grudge against him. At her encouragement, Lorenzo tampered with Cesar's magic box, causing him to fall to his death. Afterward, Lorenzo seized his master's property, and The Weasel set about tarnishing Cesar's reputation. Over time, Lorenzo began to be tormented by guilt, but Jemma, remaining free, could take care of his loved ones, so he could not reveal her secret.

Neither Lorenzo nor Jemma wrote the threatening letter, as Lyney himself wrote it with a message to The Weasel. Lyney and Lynette were the children who learned magic tricks from Cesar. They remembered the good he had done for them, so they decided to clear his name of crimes he had not committed. Lyney remembered Cesar's advice to find his truth. Truth can take many forms — prized possessions with nostalgic value, fervent hopes and dreams, and irreplaceable people. For Lyney, this truth was Lynette. Life took many things from Jemma, and the wounds in her heart could no longer heal. Stealing helped her forget and ease the pain, but after Cesar's death, she stopped stealing. Lorenzo was willing to give everything up for Jemma's sake, and all these years, he helped ease the pain that only theft could previously cope with. Besides the murder, they were the only friends each other had, and deep down, Lorenzo was her "truth" that nothing could replace. As Lyney had promised, he took the thing most dear from Jemma — Lorenzo.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Congratulations on your freedom, Jemma.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Your freedom will cost you dearly. From now on, you'll be all alone in a world full of lies and falsehoods. I do hope you'll be able to bear it — you've still got a long life ahead of you, after all."</color>

In Cesar's memory, Lyney performed the "high-altitude escape" trick, and the morning after the performance, Jemma surrendered to the Gardes. Her last wish was to see Lorenzo again.

customize.text: Court of Fontaine
Court of Fontaine

The Court of Fontaine is the main city of Fontaine, where the residence of the last Hydro Archon Furina was located. The Court of Fontaine can be reached via the Clementine aquabus line, leading from Romaritime Harbor. The city amazes with its sophistication, majesty, and technology. One of the main attractions of the city is the Statue of the Seven, located near the Palais Mermonia. Gardemeks can be seen on the streets keeping order, as well as Melusines from the Marechaussee Phantom, and smartly dressed ladies and their dogs.

The Fontinalia Festival takes place in the Court of Fontaine. It was established to honor the legendary Lochknights who searched for the Oceanids and welcomed the first Hydro Archon Egeria. Similar to other prominent festivals like Mondstadt's Windblume Festival and Liyue's Lantern Rite, it holds deep connections to the founding of Fontaine, making it one of the nation's most important festivals. Originally, people commemorated the Lochknights by imitating them, wearing special costumes, raising golden cups, and going door-to-door requesting pure water. However, Furina made the tradition more festive a few years ago by changing the water request to sweets. The festival is considered to be more carnival-like now and is popular among children who engage in "trial or treat" activities each year which include going door-to-door asking for candies with baskets during the celebration. During the first Fontinalia Festival, the Traveler and Paimon attended, and the prestigious "Furina Award," named after the former Hydro Archon Lady Furina, was given out at the end of the festival. Despite the changes in leadership, the name is still fitting for the award as Furina remains a beloved figure in Fontaine.
One day, Lepine-Pauline, a specialist in Graph Adversarial Technology, decided to use an improved Kamera lens to rid Teyvat of everyone out there who's trying to con innocent people. She read in The Steambird that <color=#ffffffd9>"Several keen-eyed thieves who noticed a flaw in the Gardemeks detection systems disguised themselves as Blubberbeasts during the commission of their crimes."</color> Completely blind to the would-be-Blubberbeasts, the Gardemeks made no attempt to intervene in the thefts committed by the gang. She had an idea that it was possible to improve the Gardemeks' ability to recognize targets in order to recognize criminals in disguise. Lepine-Pauline decided to collect sample images and, based on them, develop a simple but powerful and highly accurate image recognition algorithm that runs on a small graphical processing module. Any clockwork meka installed with this module would instantly be able to recognize people wearing disguises and accurately assess the criminal threat they pose. She hoped that her invention would make her incredibly rich and even borrowed a large sum from the bank to develop her technology.
It turned out that the news in The Steambird was a short story mailed to them by an anonymous amateur author, written in the style of a true story. Although the editors of the newspaper were afraid that the story could mislead readers, the Maison Gardiennage supported them in printing it. They figured that the false intel would be a great way to dupe potential criminals into wearing ridiculous costumes when breaking the law. Since the publication of this story, the Maison Gardiennage has made a slew of arrests including "Phantom Blubberbeast," a "Titanic Redcrown Finch," and a "Specterman" as the recognition function of the Gardemeks worked perfectly. Lepine-Pauline was ready to fight the Gardemeks to be sent to the Fortress of Meropide in order not to pay off the loan, but the newspaper's journalist Charlotte, whom the researcher asked to advertise her technology, offered her an alternative use for the device. The "Kamera Lens for Image Recognition Sample Collection" was specially designed for high-fidelity image capture and analysis. The rapid focal length adjustment could be a very useful function in its own right. It would make journalists' jobs much easier and had the potential to revolutionize Fontaine's news media. Thus, Lepine-Pauline regained her hope of becoming rich, and Charlotte got news material: <color=#ffffffd9>"The boundaries between real news reports and news-like fiction must not be blurred, even when there's a compelling justification for doing so."</color>

One of the Lil' Fungi's Fun-Tastic Fiesta events, Fungus Mechanicus, took place in the Court of Fontaine, organized by the Fungi trainer, Haniyyah, and her writer friend Souka. Haniyyah had come to Fontaine to search for reliable investors for the official Fungi tournament, and to host a preview event to advertise the Fungi's cuteness and attract an audience in advance. Haniyyah also wanted to find researchers from the Institute to make a new Wisdom Orb that would allow humans to tame the Fungi. The Fontaine Research Institute's Fonta research team didn't just provide a huge amount of funding to Haniyyah and Souka, but they also promised to help them look for the necessary talent.

Souka prepared preview event plans, ordered elegant clothes, and trained the Eremite Haniyyah to improve her speech and manners. In the new competition, people were directing Fungi to defeat all the Mechanici. The game received a pretty good initial response, but it was lacking in long-term potential, so it quickly lost popularity, so Souka combined elements from various documents and fiction to change the Mechanici into pieces that simulate powerful opponents, which adds all manner of variables to the game. She also went to The Steambird to discuss the possibility of placing an advertisement in the newspaper to popularize the game. Turenna, a member of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, was put in charge of monitoring the exotic animals brought to Fontaine from abroad, as well as providing highly skilled assistance to Haniyyah and Souka. The Traveler and Paimon's friends, Bongo-Head and Kindlejoy, were even assigned special people to take care of them.

customize.text: Court of Fontaine: Court Region Waterway Hub

The Waterway Hub is located on the square in the Court of Fontaine with the fountain. The elevator connects the Palais Mermonia and the Clementine aquabus line leading to Romaritime Harbor. The third line, the Callas line, leading to the Research Institute, was damaged during the explosion of the Central Laboratory. The President of Spina di Rosula, Navia, is planning to restore the Callas line. The main hall of the station is on the first level out of four, the Clementine line is on the second, and on the third level is the Navia line leading to the Erinnyes. At the Waterway Hub, Certified Players, Rhemia, and Pruniere can be found. Rhemia is a Melusine who serves in the Marechaussee Phantom and is quite interested in the humans around. Rhemia has recently begun playing Genius Invokation TCG with passersby, engaging in friendly conversation with them as well. The prowess she displays in these matches has earned her a lot of respect. Pruniere is an Aquabus Maintenance Worker who ensures the integrity of the waterways. After finishing the basic water maintenance work, Pruniere still has a surfeit of free time, and thus has developed superb skill at playing Genius Invokation TCG.

customize.text: Court of Fontaine: Vasari Passage

In the main square of the Court of Fontaine, in the Vasari Passage, a large moving fountain and the Court of Fontaine Waterway Hub are situated. Certified Player Paban can be found here. He is a newsy who sells The Steambird and is considered the Court of Fontaine's own miniature "Know-It-All" by some others his age. Paban has recently taken to playing Genius Invokation TCG with those who come to him for information, offering them the following deal: If he wins, his opponent must become his distributor.

In addition, various merchants can be found in the passage, such as a fruit vendor and Certified Player, Eugenie, a manager of a snack shop, Louis, and Boucicaut from Damoville Purveyor. Next to the Gallery is the building where the rival of the famous fashion designer, Chiori, lives. When he falsely accused Chiori of collaborating with criminals, she called the captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, Chevreuse, to prevent Chiori from overdoing it in the "conversation." The Beaumont Workshop, owned by Estelle, is also located there. The workshop offers a full, comprehensive service for individual orders. To order, prepayment, documentation with requirements, and supporting documents are required. Forging in the workshop is carried out by a special machine running on Indemnitium. Previously, during trials, the Oratrice Mecanique d'Analyse Cardinale collected people's faith in justice and converted it into energy, which was then used throughout Fontaine. In addition to Indemnitium, Fontaine has Pneumousia energy, which is produced independently of the Archon's power but is unstable in nature. When Fontaine's prophecy had not yet come true, Estelle helped the Fatui make Magic Pockets in which people could put all their things in case of danger. At the time, Estelle owed money to Confrerie of Cabriere. She promised to repay her debt by the end of the month, but the people from Confrerie of Cabriere wanted to get seventy percent at that moment. It turned out that Confrerie of Cabriere owed money to the Northland Bank. The Fatui Harbinger Childe went to collect their debt and stopped to talk to the Traveler returning from visiting Estelle.
When Furina left her role as Archon, she quickly left her residence and went to live in a small apartment. Although she had gained her freedom and fulfilled her duty, she did not know where to go next. The concept of "freedom" rang hollow. Furina's luggage remained piled up in her new rental apartment, and she lacked all will even to tidy up or get moved in. All she could do was lie in bed and stare at the bare ceiling. One day, Clorinde the Champion Duelist, who had previously been under her command, visited her. The duelist was shocked at Furina's living conditions, quickly expressing her willingness to pay for better accommodations, a notion Furina expended no small amount of effort disabusing her of. Despite this, she was dragged, however reluctantly, into at least properly unpacking and tidying up the room, and now Furina lives in the Vasari Passage.

Not far from this apartment was the meeting place of the theater troupe that Furina helped once. After she became an ordinary person, she never wanted to go on stage again, but after learning about the history of the troupe, she decided to become an artistic consultant for the last time in the play "The Little Oceanid." The main actress, suffering from illness, was unable to appear in the final scene of the play, so Furina had to replace her. After a wonderful performance and communication with the troupe, Furina decided that perhaps she would return to the world of theater.
One day, the Chief Editor of The Steambird, Euphrasie, told the Traveler about an order that had been kept in the editorial office for six months. In the order, an elderly man, Benoit Leroy, asked to find assistants. When Traveler and Paimon volunteered for the task, they saw Benoit looking depressed and scared next to his daughter, Morticia's, husband. After investigating and talking with Morticia and her husband, it turned out that Morticia's real name was Autumn, and Benoit was her adoptive father, who sold her as a wife to a rich man for the sake of inheritance. When Autumn's first husband died, Benoit received that house in the Vasari Passage and gave his daughter to her second husband, with whom she had a daughter. Later, Autumn killed her husband, for which she was sent to the Fortress of Meropide, and her daughter remained with Benoit. He gave the girl up for adoption without saying a word to Autumn. Autumn and her "husband," Athos, escaped from prison to take revenge on Benoit and find the girl, but even after learning the truth, Autumn did not dare to invade the happy life of her daughter. Molli was adopted by a caring and rich family who tried to protect her from Benoit.

In this place, the Café Lutece is located, owned by Arouet. He previously worked in the Maison Gestion, and his views there were considered quite radical. When Arouet got tired of work, he quit to open a cafe. Now he is a coffee maker of the highest level. Café Lutece is the most popular сafé in the Vasari Passage, its delicious coffee and snacks earning plaudits from customers from all backgrounds to freely and comfortably discuss philosophy and other topics as they enjoy their coffee. Anyone may participate, and no topic is forbidden, with the exception of "death."

customize.text: Hotel Bouffes d'ete

The Hotel Bouffes d'ete, situated in the Vasari Passage, is a lovely building with clean walls and sparkling windows, and well-mannered, well-groomed children frequent it every day. Unlike other mansions of comparable beauty in the Court of Fontaine, the registered owner of this property does not live on-site. Indeed, nearby residents have not even heard of her. The signature on the relevant documentation is but a false identity — the real power lies with someone else. If one could hear the children whisper at night behind the Hotel's closed gates, one would hear this appellation: "Father." When speaking of "Father," some faces turn worshipful, some hearts are seized with fear, and still others look inscrutable, torn — but their tone always becomes one of respect. These children are part of the organization known as the House of the Hearth. They belong to the Fatui. This place is home to orphans the world over, and the luxurious Hotel is but one of the House's faces. As for this "Father," the master of the House, she is none other than The Knave, Arlecchino, presently Fourth of the Fatui Harbingers. The Fatui — and this Harbinger — enjoy a mixed reputation. But to most of these children, "Father" is the most important figure in their lives. <color=#ffffffd9>"It is only because 'Father' is here that this place is truly like a 'home.'"</color> All children consider each other brothers and sisters and often hold family barbecues.

Arlecchino herself also grew up in the House of the Hearth under the former headmistress and Fatui Harbinger, Crucabena, known as "Mother." Crucabena arranged duels between children for the title of "king." A year after
became the only surviving winner, she killed Crucabena and buried the title "Mother" with her. The Tsaritsa personally bestowed a new name on Peruere and entrusted her with being the first to use the Hydro Gnosis of Fontaine. Rules in the new House of the Hearth are quite strict, but not ruthless. The house became a common shelter for the children, which they had to support through joint efforts. Now, everyone was free to choose their own way of completing tasks, and even if they failed, they were not subjected to the same painful punishments. If they broke the rules or wanted to leave, they were given a bottled flame, a solution of fire in Arlecchino's blood, which destroyed all the person's memories of the House of the Hearth.
The House of the Hearth uses many codewords to maintain operational security and secrecy, and of these, "Marelle" was personally selected by The Knave herself. "Marelle" takes its meaning from a popular Fontainian children's game. Boxes sequentially marked with numbers are drawn out on the ground, a sandbag is thrown into one of the boxes, and the player will jump from box to box in a specific order. No one knows when this game began to spread, nor who created the rules, but all young children of the Hearth have experienced being taken by older children to play the game. The memories married to "Marelle" were always wonderful, like the kiss of radiant sunshine. As such, at first, the children were perplexed when their "Father" was torn between assigning "At Ease" or "Danger" to that codeword. Little did they know that in the House that came before, Marelle was no game. In those days, each and every child would leap into the boxes one by one under the vigilant eyes of the adults. Stepping out of the lines or breaking the rhythm was not allowed. There was never a need to ask for the punishment for making a bad jump, for the area outside of the boxes was lined with upturned blades. Those who lost their balance, whose stamina failed, or simply made an error out of fear, so many fell beyond the bounds, and the dark-red soil mourned that painful past. None would have associated it with being "at ease" — indeed, few could speak of it without blanching. Yet, after her hesitation, Arlecchino chose "at ease" as the codeword's meaning that day. Marelle was by then no longer associated with "danger." Now, all that came to mind when this game was mentioned were smiling faces. In which case, she thought, let those unhappy memories dwell in her heart alone. Let the blood and dust be wiped away, for children to see a broader future.
Famous magicians, Lyney and Lynette, grew up in the House of the Hearth. When they were still living on the street and performing magic tricks to earn a living, one aristocrat from the public decided to adopt them. At first, the children thought that the hard days of wandering were behind them, but the aristocrat needed a pocket magician, not a son. He took Lyney to banquets and parties to garner attention, which he would then use to expand his social circles. After another performance at the banquet, Lyney discovered that Lynette had not returned with him. It turned out that one "eminent person" liked her at the banquet, and the aristocrat presented her to him as a gift. Lyney ferreted out the location of the mansion of that so-called "eminent person" and went there that night. When he went inside, he saw only the floor stained with blood and the silhouette of Arlecchino in the dark. Lynette and several other girls were rescued. The Harbinger saw something in Lyney and invited him and his sister to the House of the Hearth: <color=#ffffffd9>"The House of the Hearth welcomes you, for your interests align with ours. Here, none will ever betray you. Indeed, betrayal shall never be permitted here."</color> At first, Lyney did not trust Arlecchino, but she dealt with the aristocrat who adopted them, giving them freedom. Over the course of several years, Arlecchino killed all members of the family who bought Lynette.

While Hotel Bouffes d'ete's operations in Fontaine work toward a just cause, its methods can often be radical. Only the influence of "Father" and her control over the inner workings of the Court of Fontaine prevent any serious incidents from occurring. There was once an official funded by Lyney who served in the Maison Gardiennage. This person provided both intel in support of the Hotel's operations and scrubbed clean the effects of some of the Hotel's clandestine actions. These were actions that came with no small risk, but the official always performed them well, for he believed that the Fontaine of the present day needed someone like "Father" who could bypass the many layers of laws and regulations and take direct action. The official's deeds were eventually discovered, and on the brink of capture, he used an emergency communication device to send a message to Lyney. Upon discovering the device, the Gardes who arrived at the scene mocked the official's naivete, claiming that the signal sent merely informed his compatriots to save themselves — no one would be stupid enough to try to save him. The official's reply was also quite simple — even such an ending would have been fine for him, for he did not believe that his prior cooperation was the wrong decision. He still believed that he did the right thing by starting to cooperate with them. As the Gardes were taking him away, he was suddenly rescued by Lyney and Freminet, making the Gardes think that he had flown away in a flying machine.
Despite the formidability of the Harbinger, she cares for her children and accepts their peculiarities. One day, a girl broke the rules and wore jewelry on a mission. When the girl later realized that she had made a mistake, she took off the necklace and fearfully waited for Arlecchino's reaction, trembling with fear. But she took the necklace and put it around the girl's neck, and then tied her hair with a velvet ribbon and put earrings with precious stones in her ears.

<color=#ffffffd9>"It is normal to be vain at your age. But do not let these beautiful trinkets arouse vanity and dull your intellect. Wear them. Once you have grown accustomed to them, you will realize that no gem, however exquisite, is any more than an object, cold and dead. This is your new lesson — to understand the source of your emotions. Master them, use them. Never be their slave."</color>

When one of the children of the orphanage, Freminet, went in search of his mother and was about to give up, "Father" threw him his mother's medallion. All these years, Crucabena told him that his mother abandoned him, but the truth turned out to be different. That year, the debt that his family owed finally reached the point where they would no longer be able to repay it. Those greedy moneylenders had not only forced Freminet's mother to hand over the house that they lived in but had also demanded that she hand over Freminet as well. In the end, she had no choice but to entrust Freminet to "that orphanage" — somewhere they could never get at him — and then face them alone. When Arlecchino killed all the moneylenders, it was already too late for Freminet's mother.

For a long time, the House of the Hearth tried to resist Fontaine's prophecy about the dissolution of people. All the orphans were Fontainians and would do anything to save their homeland. So, the children of the House of the Hearth distributed Magic Pockets to the Fontainians, in which they could place personal belongings in case of a sudden threat. In addition, Arlecchino conducted an investigation about the Gnosis: she had long suspected that Lady Furina did not have it, so she sent the children to the Opera Epiclese and to the Fortress of Meropide to find out the truth. During the fulfillment of the prophecy, Arlecchino and the other Fatui took a direct part in evacuating, helping residents, and rebuilding damaged areas.
On the Hotel Bouffes d'ete's Founding Day, all the children were abustle, draping festive colors all over the place. To the residents, outside festivals and events were cold and emotionless things, foreign elements in their lives, and only this dwelling could bring them true warmth. The children were preparing for the holiday with all their might: Lynette, along with other children, pulled ribbons and hung up handwritten congratulatory posters, Freminet monitored the serviceability of the magic props, and Lyney was preparing a secret magic trick. And thus, the banquet was successfully held with everyone's support. The children danced to the joyous music playing from the grand hall's phonograph and enjoyed delicious food — this was the birthday of no one in particular, but this was the day they all felt they had gained new lives. The final act was a magic performance: a magic box was placed in the center of the room, and when all the candles went out, Lyney announced that the most important present in their lives would appear from there. Under the explosions of firecrackers, the box opened, and Arlecchino appeared before them. Everyone froze, but "Father" was not going to reprimand anyone. On the contrary, in her opinion, Lyney deserved praise for keeping the secret well and being able to achieve the desired effect from the trick. That night, the children and their "Father" delighted in the various desserts together, and she personally sliced a serving of cake for each of them, which she herself enjoyed some of as well. Perhaps the most amazing aspect of Lyney's Founding Day magic show was its ability to have even "Father" lay down her heavy burden and enjoy a brief moment of familial love.

customize.text: Emilie's Perfume Shop

In the Vasari Passage, Emilie's perfume shop is located. Emilie moves much like perfume herself: you cannot reach her, nor can she be stopped. She is not employed by the Confrerie of Cabriere, nor does she work with any fixed brand. Nevertheless, she remains the most famous perfume designer in Fontaine, and the elegant, fashionable ladies of Fontaine would even give a precious gem for her perfume. The cost of one bottle of perfume can reach 570,000 Mora. Chiori, the owner of the Chioriya Boutique, entered into an agreement with her, according to which Emilie supplies small quantities of perfume to the Chioriya Boutique. The worker then secretly sprays them in the fitting room, and Chiori informs Emilie about the customer reviews.
Emilie has expert knowledge in the field of chemistry and often assists the Maison Gardiennage in analyzing evidence and tracking down a killer. She helps them discover information that no one else can see, like what type of perfume a suspect wore or what type of flowers they sent as a gift. She can even determine the places they've been, right down to the very dirt they've stepped in. She once helped the captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol catch a criminal who committed murders based on the book "The Two Musketeers." The killer left rainbow roses near the victims, and Emilie was able to figure out that they belonged to a rare variety of flowers and tracked the nursery down to the house.
Despite the popularity of Emilie's perfumes, perfume-making is just a hobby for her, something she does in her spare time, just like how some people learn to play a musical instrument or make crafts. Her real profession is a forensic cleaner. Her mother is a forensic pathologist, and since she was little, Emilie knew that she wanted to work in the field of criminal investigations, just like her mother. For a long time, her talent for chemistry inspired her to pursue trace evidence analysis. As she progressed further in her studies, she began to encounter real-life crime scenes. One day, she saw a child's murder scene and could not imagine how the child's parents would clean up the crime scene. So, she decided to become a forensic cleaner and use her chemicals to clean crime scenes.

customize.text: Court of Fontaine: Quartier Narbonnais
The Steambird

Quartier Narbonnais is home to some of Fontaine's most influential perfume and clothing stores in fashion circles, and tourists interested in Fontainian fashion often go there. One of the main buildings in the quartier is The Steambird, Fontaine's most popular newspaper. Euphrasie is the Chief Editor of the newspaper, and she shoulders a great many responsibilities in addition to her work at the agency — she posts commissions for local residents' everyday troubles, assists the Palais Mermonia in putting up posters for criminals and dangerous monsters wanted by the Maison Gardiennage, and taps into the newspaper's powerful sources to find and contact people best suited for the missions. The symbol of The Steambird is the mechanical pelican Sir Arthur, whose voice module stores the latest news from the Court of Fontaine. One day, Sir Arthur was kidnapped, and the Marechaussee Phantom worker, Talochard the Melusine, volunteered to solve the case, along with the intelligent lie detector "Curve." It turned out that the editor of the newspaper, Jenck, was involved in the kidnapping. He learned how 30 years ago, the newspaper wrongly accused the creator of Curve of falsifying research results, which led to the death of the researcher in a judicial duel. Jenck contacted one of Fatui's agents in the Fleuve Cendre and made a deal with one of the Harbingers: in exchange for documents from the researcher's secret laboratory, they promised him the position of editor-in-chief of the newspaper. In the laboratory, he tried to kill the Melusine, Curve, the Traveler, and Paimon, for which he was punished by the Harbinger, who did not want to be in enmity with the Traveler. Jenck's tongue was torn out, and a note of apology was placed in its place.

One of the journalists is Charlotte, who chases not just surface-level stories, but their root cause. Charlotte's father, Galanopoulo, is a seasoned reporter and professional nature photographer, and it was he who noticed his daughter's interest in and knack for "observation." For her tenth birthday, he gave her a custom-made Kamera, which Charlotte named Monsieur Verite, which means "truth." Renowned fashion designer Chiori later created a costume for the Kamera. Charlotte has a special talent for photography, and when her father sent her first photographs to The Steambird, the critics were immediately fascinated by them. When Charlotte became famous for her photographs, Euphrasie approached her in the hope that Charlotte would become a special correspondent who would conduct interviews and write articles in addition to taking photographs. At first, her father was strongly against his daughter communicating with full of ulterior motives or hypocrites, but she realized that the world was full of undiscovered "truths" that she wanted to dig up. So, she became a full-fledged journalist for The Steambird and later, thanks to her unique reporting, received several La Verite awards, the main prize for Fontaine journalists.

One of her most famous articles is "Prestige Prize Proved Perniciously Partial — The Real La Verite," which tells the story of money transactions and bribery of members of the La Verite committee. The article caused a stir throughout the Court of Fontaine, and amidst a broadside of shutter clicks, Charlotte unleashed a barrage of questions on the dumbfounded committee members. They tried to justify themselves, but in the end, they declared the questions out of order and in violation of normal procedure and fled in front of the journalists. However, Charlotte's reporting did not end there, and she continued to write about editorial staff associated with the committee. As a result, the Maison Gardiennage declared an official inquiry into the Award, suspending its activities and investigating all suspicious awardees. By court decision, the La Verite Award selection committee was also wholly reorganized, now under various forms of new oversight.
Astrologist Mona Megistus from Mondstadt writes a column in The Steambird called "All Things Astrological." Mona initially took the job to support herself. Her contributions to a column about constellations in The Steambird have become her most stable income source, but she immediately shells out on more astrology-related resources, returning to a state of destitution once more. Mona had the opportunity to work for newspapers by pure chance. When the previous contributing author was traveling the world, he heard the story of a strange astrologist, and his hobbyist's curiosity compelled him to seek her out. Their correspondence left him deeply impressed. As it happened, he was also looking to retire, and seeing that Mona was strapped for Mora, reached out to help her by recommending her to the editor-in-chief of The Steambird. When Mona released her first column, "An Introduction to Astrology," the column, heretofore known for being easy reading, experienced a massive shift in tone. Most of each issue was dedicated to discussing the movement of celestial bodies and other difficult (and obscure) topics. Academic quotations, dense footnotes, and even the occasional hand-drawn star maps abounded in these writings. The editor-in-chief could not help but feel worried that this approach was too academic. Would it find acceptance with long-time readers? As it turned out, there was no need to fret. The publishing house received a great many letters that read something like this: <color=#ffffffd9>"Wow, this is amazing. I don't really get it, but this is super interesting. Consider me a fan of Astrologist Mona Megistus."</color>

Long before Fontaine's prophecy came to fruition, The Steambird sent an invitation to Mona to take part in a panel and speak about the circulation of the prophecy as an astrologist. Back then, no one knew what kind of trouble Fontaine would be in.
Salon Caritat is located near the Hotel Debord. One of their employees is Riqueti, a former worker of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol and the Maison Gestion. To further the study of the law in Fontaine and improve the administration of justice therein, this salon organizes the 36th symposium. The symposium's topic is: "The Current State of Budget Overruns of the Maison Gardiennage and its Connection to the Provision of Public Safety in the Court of Fontaine."
