customize.text: Hotel Debord

In the quartier, the Hotel Debord, a famous restaurant, is located. Thirty years ago, there were only four tables, eight chairs, and a waiter who was also the owner. But today, Debord has exquisite carpeting, expensive decorations, two dining areas, and an endless stream of guests. Its owner believes that <color=#ffffffd9>"Art is the best seasoning for good food,"</color> and will often invite artists from various walks of life to perform at the restaurant. The intricate interior design also ensures that guests will be able to view the performance no matter where they sit. For those who love art, such displays may be even lovelier than choice food. At the restaurant, you can try Fontainian Foie Gras alongside this red wine blend of Sassica and Ornella, produced on Erinnyes, as well as a special cake that goes on sale only once a week. The waiter at the restaurant, Sanguinetti, believes that not every well-dressed gentleman or lady is as elegant in their tastes as their appearance might indicate. The question about the oldest and most expensive wine terrifies him.

The Hotel Debord was founded about 100 years ago by adventurers Modeste and Savelli. One day, they discovered an extract of the Lumitoile that the Remurians used to heighten their senses, and with it, they created the famous Gateau Debord, which sold only sixteen servings a day. Modeste was hailed as a genius and the greatest chef in Fontaine, while Savelli was called a mediocre and a failure. In the prime of his life, Modeste suddenly died, and rumors began to spread in the Court of Fontaine that Savelli was to blame. With Modeste's death, the decline of the Hotel Debord began. The restaurant was constantly moving, its owner changed many times, until it finally fell into the hands of Vaneigem.

When Lady Furina was still the Hydro Archon of Fontaine, she tasted a dessert that took the Court of Fontaine by storm, and the very next day, she invited the chef, Escoffier, who had created the dessert, to work at the Palais Mermonia. The palace's limited budget and lack of advanced equipment meant that she could only prepare simple dishes, preventing Escoffier from fully demonstrating her culinary genius. As a result, she needed a well-equipped restaurant where she could prepare desserts for Furina, then carefully pack and seal them, and deliver them to the court. Then the owner of the Hotel Debord, Vaneigem, made an offer to Escoffier, creating a special position for her as "Technical Head Chef." Now she was formally on par with the hotel's head chef and was free to use even the rarest and most expensive ingredients to create unrivaled dishes for Lady Furina. At that time, the head chef was an old and experienced woman who had already chosen her successor. However, seeing Escoffier's advantages in all areas of culinary art, she decided to give the two young chefs the opportunity to measure their strength in a friendly competition. Escoffier did not disappoint the expectations placed on her. She cooked a bowl of Wave-Kissed Sands — a dish that appears simple and unassuming at first glance but whose preparation is fraught with potential pitfalls. The dish left those who tasted it stunned, and even her rival was convinced that Escoffier should take her place as the new head chef. Thus, Escoffier became the youngest head chef in the history of the Hotel Debord. The commemorative badge that Furina had given her — now a symbol of her personal image — would grow to embody the pinnacle of cutting-edge gastronomy. Under her leadership, the chefs of the Hotel Debord expanded the boundaries of the possible, improving the quality of each dish in their repertoire. Even the most pedantic critics could not find any flaws in their work. In just six months, Escoffier had reached the pinnacle of her profession. She was declared the most celebrated chef in Fontaine after Modeste and was able to recreate the recipe for his famous cake, changing some of the ingredients. In keeping with tradition, this cake is also sold in only sixteen servings a day.

The special ingredient that Modeste and Savelli added to the Gateau Debord actually sharpened all the senses, including taste, gave people energy, and for some time, a person would become unusually receptive, and then discover a gradual decrease in taste sensitivity. Over time, Modeste began to believe that the taste of the Gateau Debord had changed, although people said that they did not feel the difference. The chef always strived for perfection; he did not tolerate even the slightest flaws, so he immediately stopped selling the Gateau Debord and locked himself in the kitchen, devoting days and nights to research and experiments. But with each new attempt, he only moved further away from the original taste, until one day he realized that he could not even taste coffee. And then it became clear that it was not the Gateau Debord that had changed, but his taste buds. The most brilliant chef of his time realized that he had lost his taste forever, and in despair, he decided to take his own life, using up the last reserves of the substance. A hundred years later, the Fontaine Research Institute synthesized a drug called lumiline from the Lumitoile. It was used to treat people with impaired responses to stimuli, but overuse could have mood-altering effects and even lead to nerve damage, so it quickly ended up on the Gardes list of controlled substances. Unfortunately, some products with the addition of lumiline managed to hit the market before its side effects became known. Such products ended up in the kitchen of the Hotel Debord, and Chef Escoffier decided to take responsibility, as a result of which she was accused and imprisoned in the Fortress of Meropide. And although she didn't stay there long, she never returned to the Hotel Debord, but became a chef at the Spina di Rosula tavern in the Fleuve Cendre.

After Escoffier left, Savanna became the head chef of the restaurant. She considered herself unworthy of the job and felt guilty that Escoffier went to jail, since she was the one who bought the products that day. Over time, Savanna became increasingly aggressive: she constantly yelled at the employees, made them redo the food endlessly, and did not allow them into the kitchen. She also stayed late every day and made the Gateau Debord, but she could not replicate Escoffier's taste. One of the employees was so mentally and physically exhausted that he could not even get out of bed, and then Escoffier decided to intervene. According to an old tradition established by Modeste, a culinary duel was held between the chefs, in which Escoffier was joined by Monica from the Hotel Debord and the Traveler. Although Escoffier and the Traveler were confident in the result, it turned out that the cake was deliberately ruined, and Savanna won. As a result of her victory, she demanded the original manuscript of Modeste, an old diary where he wrote down all his recipes and thoughts, from Escoffier. Although she left a copy of the diary with Savanna, she believed that Escoffier had intentionally changed the recipe for the Gateau Debord. After receiving the manuscript, the chef found no changes in it and fainted from shock.

Although Escoffier knew that Savanna had cheated, she spent the entire night trying to figure out why her former friend's Gateau Debord tasted different. The next morning, when Savanna was supposed to return to the restaurant, she did not show up, and in her house, they found only an underwater map of the Morte Region with marks. Escoffier and the Traveler set off to rescue Savanna, and it turned out that Monica had been blackmailing her all this time. She deliberately added lumiline to the chef's food to make her more nervous and aggressive, and also brewed lumiline tea for a restaurant worker to make him sick. Monica was a descendant of Modeste, and from his manuscripts she learned about the substance that was added to the Gateau Debord. Realizing that it was not just a kitchen ingredient, but a real drug, she decided to make a fortune off of it and lured Savanna there by blackmail. When Monica was stopped and Savanna was saved, Escoffier revealed that the chef could not replicate the taste of the cake because Monica had damaged the heating elements in the ovens, and they showed a different temperature. Then they tested the culinary duel again, in which Escoffier easily won, but despite the defeat, Savanna finally believed in herself.

One day, the owner of the restaurant allowed the entire second floor to be used for filming "The Two Musketeers." The film was produced by the famous film director and creator of the Film Kamera, Xavier, and directed by Lady Furina. In addition, the owner of the Chioriya Boutique, Chiori, the captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, Chevreuse, and invited guests from Inazuma: Kamisato Ayato, Kamisato Ayaka, and Yoimiya joined the film crew. The first scene, showing the events in the baron's house, was filmed at the Hotel Debord. Filming began with two powerful scenes at the estate, starring Chevreuse as Tulipe and Ayaka as Iris. In these scenes, Tulipe and Iris's mother was poisoned, and they fled the baron's house, vowing to avenge her. The film received high reviews from film critics and won the main award of the Fontinalia Film Festival — the Furina Award.

Many merchants reside in the Quartier Narbonnais. Chesil provides the city's largest selection of gemstones and handicrafts. One day, the Traveler and Paimon brought him to evaluate an unusual ore found by the Melusine Puca near Merusea Village. The ore had an amazing shine and glossy texture, so the merchant was very interested. He hoped to make jewelry from it, but it turned out that during processing, the ore loses all its beauty and is too hard to process. Chesil was ready to give up the ore, but one of the watchmakers saw the ore left over after unsuccessful processing attempts. They liked that the ore was very strong and made parts for a clock mechanism from it. Then Chesil decided to establish an uninterrupted supply of ore for the manufacture of mechanical watches and even wanted to make a special watch with elements of the Melusine style. Books can be bought from a merchant named Hubel in the Quartier Narbonnais.

customize.text: Court of Fontaine: Quartier Lyonnais

In the Quartier Lyonnais resides the secretary of the Adventurers' Guild, Katheryne, whom adventurers can always turn to carry out assignments. Adventurers went to help the Fontaine Research Institute, a theater troupe, a clockwork workshop, and many others. If anyone has problems, the Fontainians can ask for help themselves.

Opposite the Adventurers' Guild is Bertin's House of Curiosities, a shop where one can find curiosities ranging from jewels, instruments, perfumes, and souvenirs to masterpieces. This store is technically a fashion workshop. Its owner, Mequignon, collects various curios to gain inspiration. Owing to her artistic ideals, she also exchanges collections that have ceased to inspire for Hydro Sigils from adventurers.

customize.text: Lepaute Horlogerie and Leschots Clockwork Workshop

Just behind the Adventurers' Guild are Lepaute Horlogerie, Northland Bank, and Leschots Clockwork Workshop. The workshops are headed by two brothers: Livre and Caron, who are in a strained relationship. One day, Livre planned a project called "Champion Duelist Plan," which was supposed to advertise the release of their new clockwork toys. The workers at Leschots Workshop asked the Traveler and Paimon to collect combat data for the project and conduct an investigation in Lepaute Horlogeries since the latter's toys turned out to be very popular. Caron immediately understood his brother's plan and volunteered to reveal a new toy inspired by the adventurer from Mondstadt, Bennett. They met in Springvale when Caron was about to leave Mondstadt. Bennett was unable to complete the order to deliver the food on time, as he was attacked by monsters on the way, and the dish was spoiled. Caron volunteered to help Bennett prepare a new dish, but the wood in the fire got wet, a large hole appeared in the bottom of the pot, and while they were trying to fix it, several stones flew into them from nowhere. In the end, the order was carried out, although the client complained that while eating, he broke a tooth on a stone. Bennett later showed Caron various hard-to-reach places in Mondstadt to express his gratitude. The road was not easy, but the unusually beautiful views were worth it. When Caron asked Bennett if such bad luck bothered him, he simply gave him a thumbs up and said, <color=#ffffffd9>"The world is full of all sorts of people — and maybe I just happen to be the unluckiest. But thanks to that, I've also become the bravest person — and that's given me access to sights only I can see."</color>

When Livre revealed the results of the project, the store became very popular, but few people made pre-orders, and the number of positive reviews on the board was pitifully small. People wrote that the workshop lacked sincerity, internal quality control, and modernity. Instead of working on his mistakes, Livre suspected his brother of spreading false rumors. In fact, he was still angry at his brother because of the "betrayal." Their family is known for its expertise in making clockwork mechanisms. Caron was good at making toys, and Livre was good at trading. Since they both loved toys, they agreed that when they grew up, they would open the best toy store in the world. But only as adults did they realize that someone had to inherit the family business - Lepaute Horlogerie. Livre had a strong quarrel with his father over this and went on a free voyage, but Caron remained. He was afraid that he would not be able to make a name for himself by turning his hobby into a profession, and then he would have to beg on his knees to return to the family workshop.

Thanks to the intervention of a
family disagreements were resolved. This was not the first case of such interference: since the workshops are separated from each other by the Northland Bank, they, in a sense, have already become mediators in this conflict.

In fact, Livre had long ago reserved the bank site for his workshop, but then had the idea to sell this place to the bank. He didn't want the feud to force Caron to move. In a conversation between the brothers, it was revealed that although Bennett was the inspiration for Caron's toy, it was Livre who was the real reason for its creation. Both Livre and Bennett shared an adventurer's spirit, and they were both able to turn their passion into an occupation. As a result, Livre gave his brother all the data obtained on the "Champion Duelist Plan" so that he could create something even more interesting. Now the Leschots Clockwork Workshop produces for sale a wide variety of clockwork toys, among which are penguins created by Freminet from the House of the Hearth.

customize.text: Chioriya Boutique

On one of Fontaine's busiest thoroughfares in the Quartier Lyonnais, the Chioriya Boutique, a famous fashion store created by Chiori from Inazuma, is situated. People say that the owner of the shop, who has extraordinary skill, rarely appears in the store, and if she is behind the counter, she is in a good mood. But if she's caught on a bad day, unimaginable and outrageous things may occur, such as Chiori throwing ignorant clients out of the window.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Apologies, the weather has been somewhat inclement of late. All kinds of trash have come blowing into my shop. It's been taken care of, so pay it no heed."</color> Only those who have not given up the pursuit of their dreams are worthy of the Chiori brand.
When Chiori first attended Fontaine Fashion Week, she made headlines. Some critics have opined that quality clothes are not just for looking at, but can also be "heard." In this aspect, Chiori had succeeded: every stitch and thread of her clothes told a story: the echoes of waves, the breathing of a forest, a sweet spring gushing forth in the desert.

The "old guard" of the fashion world could not tolerate Chiori for her bold ideas and declared war on her, but every one of them was defeated. One day, right before Fashion Week, the designer with whom Chiori began her journey slandered her in newspapers that she was collaborating with criminals. The designer abandoned his dream and began to create clothes for the sake of fashion, so he was angry at Chiori's success, as she did not bow her head for the sake of fashion. Almost all customers refused orders, and suppliers stopped doing business with her, but Chiori did not give up. She cut up old suits to make Fashion Week clothes and created shell accessories. Thanks to her fortitude and efforts, the truth was restored. After the successful conclusion of Fashion Week, Chiori put up a new sign with the logo on her store.

Chiori is different from all fashion designers and has her own unique approach. She sews women's suits using men's patterns, and men's formalwear from women's fabrics. It is the same for Chiori as she tailors the clothes. From the way she treats the fabric, it is as if she has never seen the material before. Her cuts come from unexpected angles, ignoring the direction of the thread, and sometimes suddenly seizing upon adding a completely new structure halfway through, before upending her own work once again. Sometimes, she will even draw her sword and swiftly cut the first-rate fabric before her with a clean slash, as though she were not making clothes, but rather dueling — as though she were fighting with the fabric in her hands, vying for authority, with her emerging as the ultimate victor.

Like the owner of the perfume shop, Emilie, Chiori often helps the Maison Gardiennage, and a nickname has been attached to the Chioriya Boutique — "intelligence boutique." The impeccably dressed merchants and government dignitaries were a kaleidoscopic flock of butterflies, each scattering the pollen known as "intelligence" from their fluttering wings onto that gorgeous flower called the Chioriya Boutique. Their actual intention was not to pollinate this flower, but rather to flaunt just how much pollen they had to the other butterflies. They consider the amount of information one has on them to be far more worthy of taking pride in than the quantity of gems sewn into one's garments. Although Chiori could not calmly work in such an atmosphere and concentrate on the costumes, she realized that such information could be useful. If the information affects the interests of her friends or concerns the safety of the Court of Fontaine, Chiori sends a letter or pays a visit to the right person.

customize.text: Palais Mermonia

The "heart" of the Court of Fontaine is the Palais Mermonia, where all government issues are resolved and social services are provided to the population. The building is found at the highest point of the Court of Fontaine and is the site where all administrative affairs in the land are handled. As far as Fontainians are concerned, the Palais Mermonia is essentially the highest authority in the land. Previously, the residence of the Hydro Archon, Lady Furina, was located there. To get to it, residents had to sign up in advance and follow certain rules. Furina's apartment had a separate entrance, so it was impossible to get there from the common room in the Palais Mermonia. One day, a man tried to jump from the roof of the palace to get to the Archon, and now he is hard at work in the Fortress of Meropide. Behind the Palais Mermonia is the beginning of the Callas aquabus line, leading to the Fontaine Research Institute.
One day, the Acrobatic Adventure Troupe performed in front of the gates of the Palais Mermonia, and during a fiery performance, they accidentally activated the Palais's fire-fighting mechanisms. As a result, many documents were damaged due to water, the troupe's license to perform was revoked, and a new law was issued: <color=#ffffffd9>"All acrobatic troupes must stay away from the area of the Palais Mermonia."</color>

To the right of Melusine Sedene, who works the front desk, is the office of the Chief Justice and current ruler of Fontaine, Neuvillette. Since Neuvillette has a busy schedule, meetings with him are available upon request through the Maison Gestion. The office of the Chief Justice contains archives of all cases considered over the past decades. After the Fatui Harbinger Childe was sent to the Fortress of Meropide for a crime he did not commit, a meeting took place in Neuvillette's office with another Harbinger, Arlecchino, who demanded Childe's handover. In reality, he was something of a bargaining chip for her, as she wanted to know the secret hidden in the Fortress and the location of the Gnosis.

One day, the Palais Mermonia conducted an investigation into a case of smuggling from Natlan: a group of merchants illegally transported Natlan relics, but were noticed by the hero of Natlan, Kinich, who immediately reported them to the port security. Kinich became a witness in this case, and it seemed that it was solved, but a few days later, a box with a device resembling a Natlan gun was found in an amusement park under construction. The woman who found the box hurried to deliver it to the palace, and Kinich again joined the investigation. It turned out that this relic from the time of the ancient dragons was brought to Fontaine by a gambler who urgently needed Mora. Pretending to be a Natlanese, he found an antique collector who was ready to buy the relic, but during the deal, an amusement park appeared in the agreed location overnight. Thanks to the intervention of Kinich, Duke Wriothesley, the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, and the Marechaussee Phantom, the criminal was caught, and Fontaine began to consider tightening measures against illegal gambling.

customize.text: Maison Gestion

In addition to the Chief Justice, the Palais Mermonia houses the Maison Gestion, which deals with documents, and the Maison Gardiennage, which includes the Marechaussee Phantom and the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol. Both of these organizations are directly subordinate to the Chief Justice. The Maison Gestion is famous for its bureaucracy and overworking employees. One day, one of the Maison's departments was notified that they must prepare letters for other departments with the information that employees were prohibited from bringing Kameras into the Maison Gestion for non-official purposes in order to avoid leakage of classified information. Similar precedents have already happened, and one employee once took a photo of his desk to show off how he arranged everything there. He was a member of the Kamera Club and showed the photo to other members, and the next day, a memo complaining that only fish gets served for dinner was all over The Steambird. The problem was that the entire Maison Gestion did not have a department responsible for Kameras, so the employee Iaune, who was assigned this letter, could not decide who to contact: the department dealing with security issues or the personnel department. People from both departments believed that the other department should be handling this issue, so they passed the buck to each other. As a result, a Gestionnaire, Roialte, suggested dividing the case into simpler parts: the duties of the security department included preventing the use of Kameras to avoid information leakage, and the duties of the personnel department included warning that Kameras could not be brought into the Maison Gestion. Although Iaune offered the same option to each department and was refused, this time they agreed to Roialte's proposals. Each department did not want to involve others in its work and bear responsibility for everything, and with the division of responsibilities, each department bore only a small part of the responsibility.
While drawing up the initiative in this case, Iaune's typewriter key disappeared. He wanted to buy a new one from the Beaumont Workshop, but since the key was the property of the Maison Gestion, repairs to the typewriter had to be carried out at the Maison's expense. If workers make repairs at their own expense and do not apply for reimbursement, then at the end of the year, when the service expenses are reviewed, this amount will not be taken into account. In this case, the calculation of funds is carried out for each item separately. First receipts are collected during the month, and then at the end of the month, they are submitted to the Maison Cardinalice for approval. This approval process is related to the approval and payment of salaries for the entire Maison Gestion. If the amount expended is too late, then the Maison Cardinalice will even need to submit it to Monsieur Neuvillette himself for approval. If he has any questions about a certain expense report, the staff member in question must submit a written report. Because of this procedure, Iaune would have to wait several months for the keys for the typewriter, so he was allowed to buy it from Estelle with a receipt to cover the costs. Since the list of items eligible for reimbursement only included "typewriter" and "key," which was a new item, Iaune had to write a letter to Neuvillette explaining why he only needed a refund for one key.
After completing the initiative, it turned out that the newest stamping machine was not working. After numerous and fruitless alignments of the document and inspection of the machine, the Traveler hit the device hard, and it finally worked. When it would seem, all the problems of the Maison Gestion were behind, it turned out that the main criminal guilty of leaking secrets using a Kamera was the person who reminded everyone of the inadmissibility of leaking information from photographs. When he took a photograph of his office, the minutes of the meeting ended up there, and the public discovered that the contents of the minutes were wildly different from what he said in his previous speeches. The news spread like wildfire, and the department became an object of ridicule. In addition, Iaune's lost key was found under another employee's desk after he submitted a request for a refund. Due to the night shifts and endless bureaucracy, Iaune fainted and was taken to the hospital.

customize.text: Fleuve Cendre

As the urban areas of Fontaine grew, the light of order drove away the shadows, and the sewers eventually became the Fleuve Cendre. Since it was difficult to maintain order, Eduardo Baker and his friends seized power in the sewers. They began to resolve disputes between the Fleuve Cendre "compatriots," bless the newly wedded, and protect the merchants from being extorted, harassed, and blackmailed by the gangs. When the authorities of the Court of Fontaine decided to purge the Fleuve Cendre, Baker was arrested and exiled to the desert. On the way to exile, he, with the help of his henchmen, fled to Poisson, taking hostage both the city itself and the members of the Maison Gardiennage who were transporting Baker. He made several unreasonable demands, so the Marechaussee Hunters, under the direction of Emanuel Guillotin, intervened. This conflict ended with many deaths, including Baker and the Mayor of Poisson. The people of the Fleuve Cendre believed that, though they lived in a city below the city with neither rain nor sun, the workers' abundant diligence and tenacity occasionally won them the right to live on the surface, and at other times turned their underground watery realm into a residence just as beautiful as the world above. After the purge of the Fleuve Cendre, some of the tools used to build this underground city were prohibited as they could be used as weapons.

Fleuve Cendre is considered a rather dangerous place where hostile forces live, but the Spina di Rosula now watches over this place. Previously, the organization could afford anything, but after the former head Callas was accused of murder and his subsequent death in a judicial duel, Spina di Rosula became strapped for cash. They now conduct much of their operations at their headquarters in the Fleuve Cendre. The organization does not allow illegal or unethical profiteering, so at the moment, it exists at the expense of funds from the residents of Fontaine who support it. In the Fleuve Cendre, members of the organization, Sonny and Luca, bartender Tetreaux, and Consigliere — a tent tortoise, adviser to Spina di Rosula, can be found. Moreover, a merchant Crossa is located there.

The Spina di Rosula tavern is run by the former head chef of the Hotel Debord, Escoffier, who left the restaurant after the lumiline case. Although the owner of the Hotel Debord called her back after her imprisonment in the Fortress of Meropide, Escoffier decided that she wanted to move on and that the restaurant could grow without her. Working in a restaurant severely limited the chef's development and her experimentation with flavors, so the lumiline case gave her the freedom to focus on improving her skills and discovering new flavors. In the eyes of discerning diners, Escoffier is both the founder of "precision gastronomy" and a leading proponent of "the principles of innovative cuisine." She excels at taking flavorings measured with the precision of scientific rigor and crafting them into dazzling, dynamic taste experiences. According to countless food critics, she is a "demon chef" who continues to breathe new life into the culinary world while sending shivers down the spines of dietary dinosaurs — those stubbornly unreceptive to change and fresh avenues in culinary evolution. While improving the industry's technology and techniques, she has successfully lowered the costs involved, effectively democratizing high-end dining and putting famous dishes on the tables of ordinary folk. According to her students and peers, she is discipline incarnate. There is no slacking on her watch — even the tiniest mistakes caused by a lapse in concentration or momentary distraction are met with scathing critiques. Crafting a dish worthy of even a perfunctory nod of approval requires absolute respect for each ingredient and the utmost sincerity and caution at every stage of the cooking process. As Navia and her other friends see it, Escoffier is a patient and thoughtful woman who finds inspiration in complex symphonies and conversations with companions alike. Joining her for a spot of afternoon tea is much like opening a surprise gift — there is always something new and unexpected in store.

Escoffier met the current head of Spina di Rosula, Navia, on her fifth birthday, when the great chef of the organization tried to recreate the famous Gateau Debord. As Escoffier approached the restaurant to at least take a look at the cake, a gust of wind suddenly brought a hat with roses into her hands. She could not find the owner for a long time, until she finally met the equally fragrant owner, the worried Navia. In gratitude, Navia invited Escoffier to try a delicious piece of cake that the great chef had saved especially for her. Escoffier's curiosity overcame her polite hesitancy, and she eagerly dug into the cake that Navia had just handed her. It was indeed delicious, yet far from perfection. To Escoffier's tastes, it was no better or worse than the other imitations she had tried. But this was a coveted gift from a new friend standing right in front of her — not to mention the work of a chef from the organization said friend's family ran, so was this the time for an honest appraisal?
<color=#ffffffd9>"How is it? Do you like it? Tell me what you really think!"</color>
Navia's appeal erased any lingering doubt. When facing a friend — when facing food — only the truth will do.
And so, as she would go on to do countless times in the years to come, Escoffier gave her frank, exacting assessment:
<color=#ffffffd9>"...It's nothing special."</color>
In the Fleuve Cendre, a Fatui agent,
suspected of kidnapping Sir Arthur, met with informants. It was he who told Editor Jenck about the secret laboratory of the researcher who created the intelligent lie detector and about the connection with The Steambird. He helped the newspaper expose the fraud of the Elegant Tableware Confrerie in the hope of obtaining inside information from the publication, but Jenck had nothing to repay him with. Then Baulard decided to enter the newspaper building and get information himself, but only discovered the disappearance of Sir Arthur and a letter threatening the editors.

During the time of Eduardo Baker, the eldest daughter, Leticia, grew up in the Randolph family of aristocrats. She was taught to maintain her noble bearing and purity of appearance, and not to show her emotions. Leticia's heart hankered after the adventure, so secretly from everyone, she changed clothes and went down to the Fleuve Cendre. She just wanted to see the lives of those base folk who had no control over their destinies. For her, this was even more interesting than Parsifal's magic. The reality was not what Leticia was prepared for, and when perils unseen — like music, lies, or poisoned wine — were about to be unsheathed and show their keen edge, she met one of her father's subordinates, Reed. He recognized her by the absence of traces of machine oil and blood on her clothes. And from her gait, it was easy to guess that she didn't often have to wear pants. Leticia fell in love with Reed and stayed with him in the Fleuve Cendre, taking the name of the rose. When she met her father many years later, he still hoped that she would return home with her child, and the Randolphs were willing to use "some Randolph magic" for her husband. In fact, her whole life was a lie. When Reed saw her in the Fleuve Cendre, he considered her a trophy that could not be missed up to enter the greatest of houses, the Randolphs. When Leticia remained in the underground city years later, his ephemeral hope had now vanished like smoke. He asked her to leave this place for the sake of the children's lives:

<color=#ffffffd9>"Dear Leticia, think of the children, of those newly sprouted trees,"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Surely they should not be born amidst cannon fire, or grow up amidst the mud and filthy waters."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Are we to nurture them with wrathful tears and hateful oaths?"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Shall we leave them to inherit confused dreams or a mission with its outlook yet unknown?"</color>

But she only replied that their future had been arranged and would be assured. Later,
with her child and husband was captured in a photograph taken during the siege of Poisson.

In the Fleuve Cendre, the workshop of Cesar, a magician and teacher of Lyney and Lynette, is situated. In addition, Uther's clothing factory is located there. When Chiori first arrived in Fontaine, she and Uther were aspiring fashion designers who dreamed of attracting the attention of the fashion world, so for some time they worked together towards a common goal. At first, they both wanted to break tradition and make unusual clothes that would bring sighs of regret into the lobby. But with every new negative feedback from clients, with every new rejection, Uther's confidence was fading. In the end, just before Fashion Week, he decided that they could not bring to life the ideas they had always dreamed of, and that was the end of their collaboration. Chiori then put everything she had on the line and gave it her all, and on the last day, she put together a collection that she was pleased with, presenting it at the show.

As a result, she received recognition and glory, and Uther has tried every year since then to destroy her business. When he falsely accused her of being associated with criminals and the poor quality of her materials, Chiori decided to take a two-pronged approach and face off against Uther at a fashion show and then attack his reputation. When Uther's factory was closed before the Fashion Show, she, along with the Traveler and Paimon, went to the Fleuve Cendre. Since the factory was always open to visitors, they calmly walked inside and found that the production itself was in the dirt. After collecting the necessary evidence, they found themselves in a trap set by Uther. Taking over Uther, Chiori sent the Traveler and Paimon with photos to the Fashion Show. The Steambird journalist, Charlotte, used the photographs they obtained to write an exposing article, and the captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, Chevreuse, arrested Uther.

customize.text: Chevreuse

When the officer of the law and father of young Chevreuse, the future captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, was accused of leaking classified information, her family moved to the Fleuve Cendre. The girl's mother grew more and more tired every day, worrying about her husband. To take care of her mother, Chevreuse didn't hesitate to take up burdens that one as young as she should never have had to shoulder, stepping into the dark currents that swirled through the Fleuve Cendre. Perhaps it was because the residents of the Fleuve Cendre had heard tell of or been on the receiving end of her upright father's care that so many helping hands were extended to her. A well-meaning shop owner gave her a job, and the couple next door often took care of her infirm mother. And when the children of the Fleuve Cendre heard that the child of a Garde had come to live among them, they flocked to her like plaintiffs and defendants, seeking her arbitration on all manner of quarrels and disputes. <color=#ffffffd9>"Chevreuse! You gotta uphold justice, y'know!"</color> So cried the children with one voice, before laughing as one. They did not truly intend to allow Chevreuse to determine who was at fault, but rather saw it all as merely another game. Yet the next day, Chevreuse brought a thick stack of legal materials when she went to see them, along with a notebook newly opened to the first page, and began speaking to the chortling children in a tone most serious. <color=#ffffffd9>"Very well. Let both sides present their evidence."</color> And from that day forward, the Fleuve Cendre had one more enforcer of the law — the littlest one around. But unlike the law enforcement officers aboveground, all judgments rendered by Chevreuse were executed under her personal supervision. There in the sewers, she learned many ways to ensure that "justice" would be upheld.
When a series of murders inspired by "The Two Musketeers" occurred during the Fontinalia Festival in Fontaine, the investigation led Chevreuse to the Fleuve Cendre. Shortly before this, one of the tavern visitors got drunk at dinner and lost his weapon, but three days later it turned up in the corner without the slightest sign of wear. In addition, residents woke up at night to the sound of gunfire. In a remote part of the sewer, Chevreuse found broken boards and several broken bottles. The criminal tried to clean up, but there were clear traces of bullets on the wall. The captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol assumed that someone had taken the weapon, brought it home, and returned it after disassembling it and examining its design. A few weeks later, they built their own musket and brought it to the Fleuve Cendre to practice shooting. A few days later, they found their target, committed a crime, and left a rainbow rose on his body, just like in the novel. The victim lived in the Fleuve Cendre. It later turned out that the killer was the sister of the author of the novel, whose mother was killed by a rich man who was trying to hide their relationship. The famous book was based on the siblings' real childhood. The deceased was an assassin sent by their father.

customize.text: Parsifal and Josephine

More than 500 years ago, two young thieving sisters who made their living cheating and stealing grew up in the Fleuve Cendre. One day, they were at the opera house and saw a comedy by Master Coppelius about an elusive thief who was a master of appearing and disappearing at their leisure. What is called magic is quite similar to fraud and theft. The first relies on acting and narrative creation, and the second relies on technique. The sisters had an idea of relying on their skills and technique to step onto the stage, under the shining lights, of using their brilliant performances to illuminate equally the dreams of those forced to stand, as well as those seated in luxurious VIP boxes. One of them would play "Parsifal," the other, her assistant Josephine. Their first performances were in Eduardo's taverns, beside the sewers, and in front of food stalls, from being before the eyes of children, brightly shining out from beneath faces stained with ash and oil, and amidst the applause of the denizens. Subsequently, they were replaced by the bright spotlights of the splendorous theater, brilliant, burning like the sun. Just as the light of their performances illuminated both the luxurious VIP booths and the standing audience, the name "Parsifal" became the talk of the town in the cities, both above and below.
During the Fleuve Cendre operation, the girl who always played Josephine rushed back home. All the people knew Parsifal, but an assistant is merely an assistant. But just as the assistant on stage is lopped in two by the sword, yet never harmed, and the missing pocket watch always returns to the audience unseen, the girl finally lost her "place" in life. And thus, she designed a "grand magic trick" that belonged to them.

<color=#ffffffd9>"It is I, the masterful magician — Parsifal 'the Great'!"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"You will bear witness to a fantastic world, never before imagined!"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Here there shall be no aristocrats, no kings — no swords shall be pointed at you!"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"None shall be born into wealth, none into poverty inescapable!"</color>

Parsifal was present at the siege of Poisson. Later, the great illusionist (or Josephine, posing as Parsifal), due to an "unexpected transgression," demanded a trial by combat, and her opponent was the Champion Duelist Marfisa. In the Court of Fontaine, everyone discussed whether Marfisa's origin would disrupt either her judgment or performance during the duel, what of her past connection to Parsifal, and which of them was the stronger fighter. For Parsifal, this battle turned out to be the last. Marfisa grew up in the Fleuve Cendre, and for as little as a slice or two of moldy bread, she would not flinch from pulling out a rusty blade to take the life of someone as insignificant as herself. She thought that everything up to this point seemed utterly meaningless, with nothing achieved and nothing to hope for. However, in spite of her expectations, death did not come. Once, she opened her eyes and saw a girl (most likely, Parsifal) smiling back gently, who then placed a flower behind her ear.

<color=#ffffffd9>"We call this flower a Lumidouce Bell, which in the language of flowers... means hope. Look, the color matches your hair."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"You have such beautiful eyes. It would be such a pity if all they reflected was despair."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Come, little lass with the sapphire eyes, let me trade this flower for your heart."</color>

Thus did Marfisa, who would later be famed as a Champion Duelist, first step into the city above ground. Watching on from the luxury of a VIP box in the magnificent theater, she could no longer remember the smiling faces of the magician and their assistant on stage, only how, as the fantasy played out, a profusion of flowers blossomed under the dazzling spotlight — bright, pure, and ever so strong. She understood that she should yet cherish hope — that this life, having now seen the light, might blossom like Lumidouce. Marfisa started copying all spear-fighting techniques she had ever seen and found expression in her performance. It seemed like she was dancing with "death" itself on a stage. Once she fought with a young swordsman and the Marechaussee Hunter, Emanuel Guillotin. She was bewildered by his crafty eyes and deceived by his intentionally slow rhythm, she finally revealed a critical weakness that she normally never would, and her arm was struck by his blade, forcing her to concede that her spearmanship was inferior. He suggested changing her approach and making "that which is immutable" and "justice" her "rule."

<color=#ffffffd9>"What right do you surface dwellers have to speak of justice? Your skills may be slightly superior to mine, yet you need not lecture me so, all high and mighty."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Sooner or later, Hunter, there will come a day when you too will fall before my lance."</color>

Despite her reply, Guillotin was right, and she became guided by justice, and offered up a cold elegy to those who would seek to evade judgment. She became a purple-clad enforcer instead, upholding justice "as it ought to be," until the fire of Poisson brought the criminal Parsifal before her. Marfisa wanted to seek out Guillotin and give him her all in a final duel, but he had long retired after what happened in Poisson. People said he hid his face beneath a mask and turned to strong drink, but the spear-wielder had to discover the truth behind the rumors for herself. After following the trail to the mask left behind by the swordsman, all her trials and tribulations seemed to have been rewarded at last. However, the end of that pursuit was most unexpected and had nothing to do with the justice sought by the once-legendary Champion Duelist. Like Emanuel Guillotin, Marfisa was dissolved by the Narzissenkreuz Ordo's members. When she fell into those pure source waters, all that had previously seemed self-evident lost its meaning. Up to the moment her memories dissolved in the water, she never knew that the Lumidouce Bell's true meaning in the language of flowers was never hope. And at the end of that long pursuit, even fate did not offer her the blossoming elegy that it ought to have.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Ah, the renowned Marfisa this time, is it...?"</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>"Take heart. Your fine spear-arm will be of use."</color>

customize.text: Marcotte Station

Marcotte Station is the terminus of the Navia aquabus line, connecting Erinnyes and the Court of Fontaine. Several fountains are installed at the station, and one of them has a lion statue. If three teardrop keys are brought to this fountain, a passage leading to the roots of the Weeping Willow, the main information center of Erinnyes, will open.

One day, a guy named Remaudiere was babysitting his sister Keratry while their parents went to the opera house. When they were walking outside, Remaudiere decided to show her a trick and "make" the fountain stop in order to take his sister home. In fact, he simply waited for the fountain to stop working, but the next day he discovered that the fountain was still not working. Remaudiere was afraid that his sister would tell his parents about his "magic," so he asked the fountain manager to fix the problem, but the fountain never worked. The Traveler and Paimon came to his aid, getting all the necessary parts to fix the fountain before the guy got into trouble.
One day at the station, the Traveler and Paimon encountered a strange, panicked woman who thought someone was trying to harm her. After calming her down, the Traveler and Paimon learned that the woman, Guijarro, was a writer who had been overthinking her detective novel to the point of becoming paranoid. She wanted to take the aquabus to the Court of Fontaine to get coffee, but she immediately imagined the many ways she could be killed on the aquabus and was unable to even board. When the Traveler escorted her to the Café Lutece, Guijarro became nervous that the coffee might be poisoned. When the owner of the café, Arouet, threatened to throw her out if she continued to scare his customers, she apologetically bought three more cups of coffee. After finishing her detective novel, Guijarro set off for Qiaoying Village in the Chenyu Vale.

customize.text: Chevalmarin Film Fantasyland

After the inventor Lepine-Pauline, with the support of the journalist Charlotte, the Traveler, and Paimon, modified the Kamera Lens for Image Recognition Sample Collection and turned it into a high-precision zoom photography assistant, it became popular in the film industry of Fontaine. After the new-generation product hit the market right as the Kamera lens was evolving, many directors and merchants began to cooperate with Lepine-Pauline, and she became a rising supplier in the film industry. People trusted her devices, so she was chosen to help build Chevalmarin Film Fantasyland, an amusement park based on the films, located on the banks of Fontaine.

The main symbol of the park was Surintendante Chevalmarin, whose official guardian is Lady Furina. She won second place in the last "Most Popular Character" poll for the comic film category, and was even dubbed "the pinnacle of round, bouncy cuteness." Many people have expressed interest in designing cushions based on her image, and Furina will receive sixty percent of the sales revenue to make better meals for Chevalmarin. Furina herself did not perform in Chevalmarin Film Fantasyland because she was aware of the scale of her roles. When she takes center stage, all attention is on her, but as a guest, she has to step back and let others shine. So, instead of performing herself, Furina decided to help from behind the scenes and became a consultant for one of the attractions.

The Chevalmarin Film Fantasyland was created by enthusiasts, and Spina di Rosula was invited to be responsible for planning, construction, and operation. In just one day, an amusement park was created on the empty beach near the Marcotte Station. To attract visitors, the head of Spina di Rosula, Navia, called her friend and chef, Escoffier, to cook for the visitors and the park's workers. For her dishes, Escoffier ordered the best vegetables and fruits from Natlan, which were delivered by Ororon and Varesa. After the opening of the Chevalmarin Film Fantasyland, Varesa stayed and opened a stall with products from her garden to advertise her brand.

The Blazing Beasts — mercenaries from Sumeru — were invited to the park as special guests. Some time ago, the Flame-Mane, Dehya, and several other members of the Eremites were invited to star in an adventure film in Fontaine. The film received good reviews, so once the director found out about the amusement park, they were invited as guests. During the filming of the film, Dehya got too carried away by one of the fight scenes and accidentally destroyed half the set, after which she was kicked out. And the mercenary who played one of the main villains was supposed to perform a spectacular dance with a sword in front of the main character, but the main actor was so hungry and in a hurry to finish the scene that he improvised and pretended to shoot him with a gun. After thinking about it, the director decided to leave this scene and, to everyone's surprise, the audience liked it.

In total, the park opened three main attractions: Eclectic Escapades, Movie Masterpieces, and Mellow Manor. Since the enthusiasts who organized the park are not full-fledged experts, but usually design event booths, special guides were developed, and consultants were invited for each attraction. Furina became a consultant for "Movie Masterpieces," in which visitors had to recreate classic scenes from famous films and play the role of legendary characters in order to overcome all the difficulties and achieve the goal. The second attraction was the "Eclectic Escapades," which incorporated popular techniques from action films, where the hero must quickly make their way through narrow alleys while being chased from all sides. The consultant for the attraction was the magician's assistant, Lynette, who enjoyed watching people's faces when they fell. The third attraction was the "Mellow Manor," inspired by light-hearted and humorous films. Various animals were placed on the territory of the attraction, including trained Fungi, large squirrels, and finches raised on special food, Blubberbeasts, alpacas, and others.

The work on the Mellow Manor was joined by the nurse of the Fortress of Meropide Sigewinne, the magician Lyney, and a special Blubberbeast that the Traveler and Paimon once saved from traffickers in Natlan and returned to Fontaine. Sigewinne wanted to visit the amusement park after hearing Navia's stories, and since there was little work in the Fortress, she agreed to become a consultant. Recently, the prison allowed inmates to spend their Credit Coupons on watching movies for good behavior, and Sigewinne was in charge of the projector in her free time, so she watched many different cartoons about animals. Unlike Sigewinne and Lynette, Lyney prefers to watch psychological horror films instead of cartoons. Before the park opened, he decided to watch all the films of a director specializing in this genre, so it took him a few days to recover from watching them. When he finally gathered his strength and went to the amusement park, he liked the attraction with animals, and even wanted to use some of them for his new tricks.

In gratitude for their help in organizing the Chevalmarin Film Fantasyland, Lepine-Pauline gave the Traveler a special bow. Many years ago, a group of weapons researchers from the Fontaine Research Institute created this prototype to push the limits of long-range bow performance, and Lepine-Pauline's team was to design a sight for it. But then, both the Maison Gardiennage and the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol adopted muskets as their standard issue, and stopped ordering bows in bulk since they require so much training to master. The research group and the team were disbanded, and the prototype remained with Lepine-Pauline, unused, until it was used as a prop in a science fiction film about "Mechanically Enhanced Warriors." The invisible protagonist, "The Prophet," used it to silently take down all sorts of enemies. The bow became popular among fans of fantasy films, so Lepine-Pauline brought it to the amusement park to demonstrate it, and decided to give it to the Traveler, the heart and soul of the Chevalmarin Film Fantasyland, the one who united all the legendary characters. After learning of the bow's original purpose, fans hoped that it would fall into the hands of a true master who could reveal its full potential, and Lepine-Pauline would like the Traveler and their friends to continue the bow's story beyond the screen.

customize.text: Fountain of Lucine

The Fountain of Lucine is the place where all the water flowing through Fontaine converges, so people like to make wishes here. The origin of throwing coins into the fountain comes from tossing Hydro Sigils into the Fountain of Lucine, which is, in fact, the correct way of making a wish to the fountain. To this day, newlyweds in love throw coins into the Fountain of Lucine, wishing for peaceful and happy lives.
All Fontainians were Oceanids once, who, according to a legend, emerged from the tear of the first Hydro Archon, Egeria. The increase in the number of the Oceanids did not require any pairing off or matchmaking. After gaining sufficient understanding and emotion, they approached the Hydro Archon or an elder for permission to "reproduce," which resulted in their division into little Oceanids. Some believed their "reproduction" served as a permit, granting permission for the dreams and desires within Oceanids to be bestowed with a new name — much like the names of childhood dreams throughout the ages. After some Oceanids became humans, they forgot about their origin. They still asked permission to "reproduce," but it was considered a symbolic act. They threw coins into the Fountain of Lucine, wishing for the children, and then their wishes were granted. People believed that the spirits in the water would bless them with healthy and happy children. When Neuvillette turned the Fontainians into ordinary people, they were able to reproduce like all other inhabitants of Teyvat.

People's tears contain the most vivid emotions: tears of absolute happiness, fear, and grief. The Fountain of Lucine is a place where water from all over Fontaine flows, so even tears that fall to the ground end up here. People who are highly sensitive to the Hydro element are able to hear these emotions contained in someone's tears. Thus, the Traveler could hear Furina's tears, struggling over Fontaine's prophecy. In addition, one day they drank the water of the Primordial Sea, which increased sensitivity, and heard the voice of a mysterious Oceanid calling Vacher. This Oceanid asked Vacher not to search for Vigneire, an adventurer who was dissolved by the water of the Primordial Sea, anymore. Vacher was her beloved once, and after losing Vigneire, he began to dissolve other women in an attempt to return his beloved out of grief. When Vacher finally found Vigneire many years later, she didn't even want to talk to him. The consciousness of all the women he had dissolved over 20 years attacked him, and Vacher died of great fright.

To the right of the fountain, a scene with the Icewind Suite is located. According to the original plan of Mr. Bossuet, a senior technician of the Fontaine Research Institute, Coppelius and Coppelia were clockwork meka dedicated to the art of dance. After Bossuet's retirement, Maillardet took over the project. He understood the concepts of "mechanics" and "dance" in his own way, so as generations passed, the functions of the "mechanical dancers" were improved, but gradually moved away from Bossuet's original design. Pneumousia was added, making them not only good at dancing but also highly capable fighters. Two different combat modes for Coppelius and Coppelia were created based on the differences between Pneuma and Ousia, Nemesis of Coppelius, and Dirge of Coppelia.

Mechanical dancers can perform many plays. For example, one is about how Coppelius lost the battle with temptation and was punished for it, about how Coppelia falls in love, but unrequitedly, and therefore almost dies. Or how Coppelia goes on a journey to rescue Coppelius from captivity. The script of "Clockwork Coppelia" was never published, but some people have collected and organized all the records to reconstruct part of the intent of Coppelius's work. One such story tells how Coppelius's plan was exposed before the Marechaussee Hunters, and how he said his final farewells to Coppelia before his punishment. Coppelius asks Coppelia to sing for him one last time.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Wind a thread about my heart, and with it, bind me tightly! Lock me up in chains and fetters, and let me be destroyed in your eyes.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>For mine heart is decided, from today forth, I shall not seek those that make me happy, but bring happiness to those I choose."</color>

Another play tells how Coppelia confesses the purpose of her journey to the youth traveling with her and resolves to follow her creator, who, in her eyes, has already passed on. She believes that when her rusted gears return to the same ash as Coppelius's bones, all sin will be forgotten.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Never again need I see the sun, moon, or stars, never again need I hear the birds singing joyously in the forests, never again need I force this lonely heart of mine to continue beating on in a world that is already bereft of he who bestowed it upon me."</color>

Ms. Qiu and her film crew can be seen near the fountain. They all come from Qiaoying Village, which is famous for its tea. Due to the high competition in the tea business, they decided to take up filming commercials for the village's tea merchants. The group made a lot of Mora from these films, but soon there were other skilled people in the village whose films featured real opera singers. So, Ms. Qiu and the others came to Fontaine to get advice from experts in filmmaking. Here they met Geisert, a master of using light and shadow to convey a narrative. His films have not yet gained much popularity in Fontaine, but they interested Ms. Qiu. While filming their film, the crew lost their camera and later dropped the film with the footage in the water. Thanks to the help of the Traveler, all the footage was returned. Later, Ms. Qiu and her team returned to Qiaoying Village to continue filming.
In this subarea, the world quest

can be found.

The gentle breezes carry the fragrance of tea all across the mountains of Liyue, filling the air with the savory scent once more.

"Tea grows upon the rocks, where jade springs endlessly flow." The faint perfume and ancient song of jade drift together along the rivers past Qiaoying Village to the bustling port of Yilong Wharf. Just what adventures and fortune await, concealed among the fog-robed peaks of the south...?

Artificed Dancers developed by the Fontaine Research Institute.

Bossuet originally intended for Artificed Dancers to be works of art that transcended the era of mechanical reproduction. But after Bossuet was forced to resign, the project was taken over by Maillardet, who had his own unique understanding of what he wanted to achieve. As a result, while their features were perfected during the course of its development, the Artificed Dancers gradually strayed from Bossuet's original vision.

customize.desc:
An artificed spare clockwork component belonging to Coppelius. It powers this artificed dancer.

The artificed dancer whirls to a platinum tune, performing an unending waltz of icewind. Coppelius's dance will not stop. He will continue whirling till the bell tolls.

customize.name: Artificed Spare Clockwork Component — Coppelia
customize.desc:
An artificed spare clockwork component belonging to Coppelia. It powers this artificed dancer.
According to its creator's design, the story of the artificed dancer with delicate joints ends at a merry moment. Coppelia will send whoever attempts to disturb that moment to a chapter of misfortune with her superb combat skills.

customize.name: Hydro Sigil
customize.desc:
A sigil that serves as a sign of recognition from the waters in Fontaine.

Offer it to the Fountain of Lucine to receive the rewards from the springs.

customize.text: Opera Epiclese

The Opera Epiclese is the most magnificent building on Erinnyes. When the Fontainians speak of the "opera house," that's what they are normally referring to. The opera house has another, more important role, besides serving as a site for various cultural performances. It is also a courtroom in which all cases in Fontaine are judged. Ever since the first diluvian period, the Opera Epiclese has stood atop the consecrated Island of Erinnyes. Overlooking the city above the waters, it symbolizes the new era's commitment to the rule of law and the pursuit of justice. The true and the fantastical, the comedic and the tragic find a stage here equally. An ancient Fontainian playwright once said: <color=#ffffffd9>"All the world's a stage, and all us merely players."</color>

Huge scales called the Oratrice Mecanique d'Analyse Cardinale stand on the stage of the opera house. This device was designed by the Hydro Archon, Focalors, and she placed her divinity along with the Hydro Gnosis there. The Oratrice converted the people's faith in justice into Indemnitium, a type of energy that powers Fontaine. If this power, accrued over five centuries, has only been used to sustain Fontainians, it could have lasted for millennia, but it has its purpose. Along with the Chief Justice, this device passed sentences in court, and its sentence has always been crucial. It once falsely accused the Fatui Harbinger, Childe, of connection to the serial dissolution case and declared the Hydro Archon guilty and to be punished via the death sentence. Although the Oratrice was used for trials, in truth its main purpose was to kill the God of Justice along with the Divine Throne when the time came. Focalors understood that only power of this magnitude could hope to destroy the Hydro Archon's Divine Throne, shaking the rules established by Celestia and breaking through the institution that is The Seven. After the main trial of the Hydro Archon, the Oratrice was destroyed, and now only the Chief Justice Neuvillette makes final verdicts.

There is a legend in Fontaine that the nation was once ruled by the Hydro Dragon, and every time the dragon cried, the sky became clouded, and rain poured down. To stop the rain, you had to shout into the sky: <color=#ffffffd9>"Hydro dragon, Hydro dragon, don't cry!"</color> Often, after tragic court hearings, even on the sunniest day, it suddenly starts raining. This was the case when the former head of Spina di Rosula Callas Caspar, accused of murdering a friend, chose a judicial duel and refused to surrender even on the verge of death.
In accordance with the relevant laws and regulations, and to ensure the best viewing experience for all audience members, no outside food is permitted within the Opera Epiclese. Visitors in violation of the rules will be expelled and punished by the Maison Gardiennage in accordance with the law. Serious offenses will be prosecuted and brought to trial, and the offender will be sentenced in accordance with the law. Moreover, visitors must be properly dressed when entering the Opera Epiclese. Should their attire not meet the prescribed standards, staff members have the right to refuse entrance. Entry is strictly by tickets, which must be booked in advance. The opera house hosts many theatrical performances and legal proceedings. Among the performances was a stage play, "The Saga of Aurelius," a trilogy based upon the epic legend about the hero Aurelius from the fallen empire. The Melusine Philharmonic Orchestra also performed there with excerpts from "Epic of Elynas" and "Ode to Judges," and the magician Lyney performed with the program "Great Magician's Night of Fantasy'' and a new "water tank escape" trick. In addition, the awards ceremony, "The La Verite Prize," takes place in the opera house. This award was organized by The Steambird and is the most prestigious and famous media award in all of Teyvat. It is used to recognize and commemorate the greatest individual and collective achievements in media, including newspapers, magazines, journals, and other media fields. Here, the trial of the magician Lyney took place, as well as the trial of serial dissolutions, the case of changing the appearance of Melusine to human, and the case of the captain of the Special Security and Surveillance Patrol, Vautrin, who avenged his Melusine friend, who died due to the fault of people.

One day, the magician's assistant, Lynette, received a threatening letter after the successful opening of the play, "The Lost Puppet." At first, another actress, Gillian, was supposed to play the main role in the play, but suddenly the director put Lynette, who did not have much experience in plays, in her place. Feeling a look of hatred on her, Lynette decided to get to the bottom of what was happening. It turned out that the letter was left by Gillian's younger sister, who blamed Lynette for what was happening. And the look of hatred came from the director of the play: he took Lynette for the role only because of her fame as a magician's assistant. For her sake, he had to rewrite the ending of the play and simplify the role of the main character. When Lynette learned the truth, she persuaded Gillian and other members of the troupe to return to the old script and cast Gillian in the lead role. Since the actress was wearing a mask, no one noticed the substitution at first, and when the identity of the main actress was revealed, everyone was too in love with her performance to talk about the deception.

Not far from the opera house, a Lumidouce Bell, meaning "separation," and a letter left by Melusine Talochard to her dead friend, a Mek named Curve, can be found. Curve was a sentient lie detector whose creator wanted him to learn to understand human lies and to lie himself. His creator died in a legal duel 30 years ago, defending his creation, and later, Talochard found Curve in an evidence room and decided to continue the creator's work. In the end, Curve died defending Talochard, having previously deceived her. In the letter, Talochard reprimanded her friend for lying but expressed her feelings to him.

<color=#ffffffd9>"Still, I don't think Dr. Mosso was right when he said that "a curve is the shortest distance between two people."</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>There are definitely some times when you should just shoot your shot straight.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>For example, I miss you."</color>

can be found.

customize.text: Chemin de L'Espoir

Chemin de L'Espoir is located on the border of the Court of Fontaine and Beryl Region. One day, a scientist from the Fontaine Research Institute, while observing maritime creatures, rescued a Blubberbeast pup from a ray-style clockwork meka that lost control. An examination showed that the pup was much weaker than a normal individual and could not survive in its natural environment. Then the researcher decided to leave it at the observation station, not far from Chemin de L'Espoir, and named it Berrypuff. When the institute's management withdrew the budget of the scientific group and directed it to "An Innovative Circuit Design Using Clockwork Meka to Simulate the Rock-Paper-Scissors Game and Its Sociological Impact," the scientist had to return.

Since he could not take Berrypuff with him, he left enough food for it to grow up and return to its natural environment. When Paimon saw the researcher's notes, she wanted to see how Berrypuff was doing. It turned out that all the food had been eaten long ago, and the Blubberbeast pup was exhausted. At first, it was timid about the treat, but in the end, it ate it greedily. After some time of regular feeding and helping other animals, Berrypuff grew up and was able to live with its friends.
Annapausis is located on one side of the location. One day, a little Oceanid named Ann's friends were in trouble, and she went from Annapausis to Chemin de L'Espoir for help. The Traveler and Paimon, who were passing by, responded to her request and went to Annapausis to save her friends.
In this subarea, the world quest Ann of the Narzissenkreuz can be found.
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Fontaine Research Institute
customize.desc: The Fontaine Research Institute of Kinetic Energy Engineering was founded by Alain Guillotin and is often shortened to simply the Fontaine Research Institute.

customize.name: Ann
customize.desc: An Oceanid created by the consciousness of Mary-Ann.

customize.name: Blubberbeast
customize.desc:
A type of mammal that resides in the watery regions of Fontaine. It communicates with its companions through melodious sounds.

Due to its density, water is a much more efficient medium of sound than air. Drawing inspiration from the Blubberbeast, someone from the Research Institute invented a type of technology that converted images into data to facilitate instant transmission. But due to the technical limitations of the experiment, it never became widely adopted outside the Institute.

In reality, however, data transmission technology based on fluid and sound has existed since ancient times. As the saying goes, there's nothing new under the sun.

customize.text: Annapausis

The gentle breeze winds through the flowery meadows in Mont Esus, setting the creaking arms of windmills to turn lazily. The peaceful and relaxed atmosphere here causes people to naturally find themselves dwelling on their most pleasant memories. Some foothills of Mont Esus by the sea, close to the Palais Mermonia. Visitors can feel the gentle breeze as they step onto the vast flower fields. According to ancient records, a magnificent palace was once built here. Named after the flowers, it sought to sing praises of love and to nurture abandoned orphans above the countless waters. Though the high tower of old no longer graces this land, the flowers remain as fragrant as ever.

Before the Cataclysm 500 years ago, Annapausis was the site of the Narzissenkreuz Institute, Fontaine's orphanage. After the fall of Remuria, the Fontainian Government decided to incorporate the Institute for raising orphans and the children of criminals into the public welfare system. In honor of the remains of the previous civilization, on the site on which the institute was located, it received the name the Narzissenkreuz Institute. As a token of gratitude to the Hydro Archon Egeria, the gentle Oceanid Lyris was placed at the head of the Institute. More than 500 years ago, Basil Elton, who grew up in the orphanage herself, became the Vice Director of the Narzissenkreuz Institute. Although sunlight never reached the Institute, it was always warm and bustling with life.

Basil told the children stories about Princess Lyris and the evil dragon Narcissus. During the Cataclysm, the Narzissenkreuz Institute was abandoned and ceased to exist. Basil Elton led the fleet of the Fontaine Armada and went to fight the creatures of the Abyss, and Lyris never understood the connection between the Cataclysm and the disappearance of the students, so she was later seen wandering near the abandoned institute. Later, she joined the radical organization, the Narzissenkreuz Ordo. Many students, including Mary-Ann Guillotin, became members of the Marechaussee Phantom or the Special Patrol, and others began to travel around the world.

During the battle between agents of the Marechaussee Phantom and members of the Narzissenkreuz Ordo, among whom were Lyris and Mary-Ann Guillotin, an explosion occurred. Mary-Ann Guillotin was on the verge of death, and Lyris hugged her, merging their consciousnesses together. From this merge, a new oceanid, Mary-Ann, was born. She was no longer Mary-Ann Guillotin nor Lyris. Wanting to remain in past memories, Mary-Ann created "The Real Annapausis," willingly becoming its captive. She created a fairy-tale house for herself, where she lived in her dreams.

One day, Mary-Ann was able to create another oceanid, Ann, after seeing her in a dream. Since Ann was part of Mary-Ann, she received part of the memories of Lyris and Mary-Ann Guillotin. Her main memory was the tale about the dragon Narcissus, which Basil Elton told to the children in the orphanage. Ann believed that her goal was to save Princess Lyris from the fairy tale, whom she thought Mary-Ann was.

Oceanid Ann, with the help of the Traveler and Paimon, went to Annapausis to save her friends and Princess Lyris from the dragon sleeping on the institute building. To enable Ann and the Traveler to get to the princess's castle, Ann's friends had to sacrifice themselves and merge together. When Ann and the Traveler walked through the endless labyrinth and found the Holy Blade of Narzissenkreuz, they discovered a book of fairy tales, through which they entered "The Real Annapausis." It turned out that Mary-Ann was the princess all this time, and she did not want to return to reality. She told Ann to live her life and do what she wanted, and then kicked them out of "The Real Annapausis," destroying the portal in the book through which they got there. When Ann discovered the truth about her and Mary-Ann's origins, she wanted to separate the identities of Oceanid Lyris and Mary-Ann Guillotin, but Mary-Ann accepted her past and decided to leave her prison.
